courses.title: Overview of Information Security
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the overview of information security, including security architecture, access control, and internet secure applications.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 111and (CMPSC 101orIST 140orCMPSC 121)
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cyber-Defense Studio
courses.description: This studio course teaches four basic hands-on cyber-defense skills: configuring a firewall, implementing a host-based intrusion detection software tool, using the Metasploit tool to do penetration testing, and implementing a network intrusion detection tool.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (CYBER 100 or CYBER 100S)andIST 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cyber Incident Handling and Response
courses.description: This course provides the student with the background, experience and perspective that is required to document organizational preparation for cyber incidents, document cyber incident impact and resolution, document response strategies, as well as integrate business continuity planning into the organization.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CYBER 262,SRA 221andSRA 231
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cybersecurity Analytics Studio
courses.description: This studio course teaches fundamental data-driven cybersecurity analytics skills using programming skills acquired in earlier courses.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200andIST 261andCYBER 262
Concurrent SRA 365
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Malware Analytics
courses.description: Malware Analytics is an intermediate course required for students who are majoring in Cybersecurity Analytics and Operations. It is a three-credit hands-on course that teaches principles and practice of malware detection, analysis, and defense.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite IST 242andIST 261andCYBER 262
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cybersecurity Capstone
courses.description: Cybersecurity Capstone is an advanced, culminating course for students who are majoring in Cybersecurity. This course provides the student with a practical exercise, designed by the instructor.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CYBER 342Wand(ENGL 202AorENGL 202BorENGL 202CorENGL 202D) and 7th semester standing

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Information Security Management
courses.description: Contemporary security issues; security management processes, architecture, and models; risk analysis and management; security planning, analysis, and safeguards; security policies development and administration; contingency planning, incidence handling, and response; and security standards and certification processes.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Information Science and Technology
courses.description: Legal environment of information technology, constitutional/political issues, intellectual property, management, e-commerce, privacy, access, computer contracting, cyberspace regulation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite IST 301orSRA 231
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor
Note Internships provide valuable experience for students; however, we recognize that situations vary and some students, due to work or other commitments, are unable to adjust their schedules. You are encouraged to contact your adviser to make arrangements for suitable activities in lieu of an internship.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Decision Theory and Analysis
courses.description: Provides an overview of decision theoretical and analytical concepts and tools in the security risk analysis field.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 211andSTAT 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: Assessment and mitigation of security vulnerabilities for people, organizations, industry sectors, and the nation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 231
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Statistics for Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This course emphasizes how to summarize data using descriptive statistics, how to make data-driven decisions using inferential statistics, and how to critically evaluate data presented in the media, all within the context of security, risk, and analysis. This is both a theory and application course. Students will learn about statistical theories, such as regression, and chi-square analyses, and apply their knowledge of these theories by analyzing and interpreting data using a statistical software package.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Computer Systems Literacy
courses.description: This is an introductory university-level course in computer systems literacy. The history, architecture and operation of computing systems and underlying computing theory are covered.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development
courses.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level of Math 21 in the mathematics placement test.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate and Object-Oriented Application Development
courses.description: Intermediate application development including algorithms, data structures, and object-oriented concepts.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 140orCMPSC 121orIST 240
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Programming for the Web
courses.description: This course will provide students with the knowledge and skills to create both basic and more dynamic web-based content pages and applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 250orIST 242orCMPSC 122orCMPSC 132

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio I
courses.description: Introductory design and development studio course for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242or permission of program
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio II
courses.description: Second of two design and development studio courses for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Grade of C or better inIST 311
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 022orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

Students will be encouraged to take introductory courses that fill enforced prerequisites in the specialization while also meeting General Education knowledge domain requirements. The student must take all nine credits in a single application focus area. Students may not mix and match.

courses.title: Overview of Information Security
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the overview of information security, including security architecture, access control, and internet secure applications.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 111and (CMPSC 101orIST 140orCMPSC 121)
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cyber-Defense Studio
courses.description: This studio course teaches four basic hands-on cyber-defense skills: configuring a firewall, implementing a host-based intrusion detection software tool, using the Metasploit tool to do penetration testing, and implementing a network intrusion detection tool.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (CYBER 100 or CYBER 100S)andIST 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cyber Incident Handling and Response
courses.description: This course provides the student with the background, experience and perspective that is required to document organizational preparation for cyber incidents, document cyber incident impact and resolution, document response strategies, as well as integrate business continuity planning into the organization.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CYBER 262,SRA 221andSRA 231
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cybersecurity Analytics Studio
courses.description: This studio course teaches fundamental data-driven cybersecurity analytics skills using programming skills acquired in earlier courses.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200andIST 261andCYBER 262
Concurrent SRA 365
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Malware Analytics
courses.description: Malware Analytics is an intermediate course required for students who are majoring in Cybersecurity Analytics and Operations. It is a three-credit hands-on course that teaches principles and practice of malware detection, analysis, and defense.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite IST 242andIST 261andCYBER 262
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cybersecurity Capstone
courses.description: Cybersecurity Capstone is an advanced, culminating course for students who are majoring in Cybersecurity. This course provides the student with a practical exercise, designed by the instructor.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CYBER 342Wand(ENGL 202AorENGL 202BorENGL 202CorENGL 202D) and 7th semester standing

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Information Security Management
courses.description: Contemporary security issues; security management processes, architecture, and models; risk analysis and management; security planning, analysis, and safeguards; security policies development and administration; contingency planning, incidence handling, and response; and security standards and certification processes.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Information Science and Technology
courses.description: Legal environment of information technology, constitutional/political issues, intellectual property, management, e-commerce, privacy, access, computer contracting, cyberspace regulation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite IST 301orSRA 231
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor
Note Internships provide valuable experience for students; however, we recognize that situations vary and some students, due to work or other commitments, are unable to adjust their schedules. You are encouraged to contact your adviser to make arrangements for suitable activities in lieu of an internship.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Decision Theory and Analysis
courses.description: Provides an overview of decision theoretical and analytical concepts and tools in the security risk analysis field.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 211andSTAT 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: Assessment and mitigation of security vulnerabilities for people, organizations, industry sectors, and the nation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 231
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Statistics for Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This course emphasizes how to summarize data using descriptive statistics, how to make data-driven decisions using inferential statistics, and how to critically evaluate data presented in the media, all within the context of security, risk, and analysis. This is both a theory and application course. Students will learn about statistical theories, such as regression, and chi-square analyses, and apply their knowledge of these theories by analyzing and interpreting data using a statistical software package.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Computer Systems Literacy
courses.description: This is an introductory university-level course in computer systems literacy. The history, architecture and operation of computing systems and underlying computing theory are covered.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development
courses.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level of Math 21 in the mathematics placement test.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate and Object-Oriented Application Development
courses.description: Intermediate application development including algorithms, data structures, and object-oriented concepts.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 140orCMPSC 121orIST 240
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Programming for the Web
courses.description: This course will provide students with the knowledge and skills to create both basic and more dynamic web-based content pages and applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 250orIST 242orCMPSC 122orCMPSC 132

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio I
courses.description: Introductory design and development studio course for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242or permission of program
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio II
courses.description: Second of two design and development studio courses for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Grade of C or better inIST 311
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 022orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: Penn State understands that you have unique aspirations. Specialized course work in this online digital journalism degree program can allow deep dives into topics of interest to your future and goals.
curriculumDescription:
Choose course work from topic areas such as:
digital journalism
: Develop the fundamental skills required to pursue a journalism and online media career with courses such as news writing and reporting, strategic communications, and news editing.
visual media
: Prepare for a career as a content producer by learning how to use striking imagery to engage viewers with courses in photojournalism and multimedia journalism.
media management
: Learn to direct, execute, and track campaigns for media companies through courses focused on digital media metrics and management, idea development and media writing, and telecom leadership.
The Bachelor of Arts in Digital Journalism and Media program requires you to complete a minimum of 120 credits.
If you are a transfer student, the number of credits you will have to take will vary according to the courses you transfer into the degree program. Once you are admitted into the degree program, an assigned academic adviser will help you with remaining requirements.
Students can earn up to six (6) COMM credits through the
credit-by-portfolio
process.
However, it is important for students to know that completing the credit-by-portfolio process does not guarantee that the credits will be awarded.
A grade of C or better is required for all courses in the major.
Students should choose an additional 11 credits to satisfy the electives requirement.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.

15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.

Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits

6 credits

Exploration:
9 credits

GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits

These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)

0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Basic News Writing Skills
courses.description: Grammar, punctuation, spelling, and word usage skills required of journalists.

courses.title: Survey of Electronic Media and Telecommunications
courses.description: The development of electronic media and telecommunications, emphasizing social, economic, political and global impact.

courses.title: News Writing & Reporting
courses.description: News and news values; legal and ethical problems of reporting; writing and reporting news for the mass media.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 160and (ENGL 15orENGL 30)

courses.title: Photojournalism
courses.description: Photography for communication in print and online; creating photographs for newspapers, magazines and the web; digital camera and software skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite or Concurrent COMM 260W

courses.title: Principles of Multimedia Journalism
courses.description: The course introduces how journalists work with the tools of multimedia and how multimedia is changing journalism.

courses.title: Introduction to Telecommunications Technologies
courses.description: Students will evaluate content creation and distribution methods and demonstrate proficiency across emerging digital products and services.

courses.title: News Media Ethics
courses.description: Ethical problems in the practice of journalism; principal public criticisms of news media; case study approach.

courses.title: Introduction to Video Field Production
courses.description: Introduction to the pre-production, production, and post production techniques when creating video content.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 260W

courses.title: Reporting Techniques
courses.description: Techniques in reporting news and trends at the local, regional, and county levels. Emphasis on both deadline and interpretive reporting.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 260W

courses.title: News Editing
courses.description: Concepts and procedures involved in processing news for various news media, but with emphasis on print media editing.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 260W

courses.title: Digital Media Metrics
courses.description: Analysis of audience data for traditional and new media to create metrics for advertising, content marketing, and audience analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 260W

courses.title: Data Visualization for Journalists
courses.description: Produce data-driven stories by demonstrating proficiency in sorting, filtering and using tools such as Structured Query Language, Chartbuilder, Tableau and Carto to query databases, as well as build charts and maps.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 260W

courses.title: Law of Mass Communications
courses.description: Nature and theories of law; the Supreme Court and press freedom; legal problems of the mass media.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGR 310orCOMM 180orCOMM 271orMGMT 215

courses.title: Internet Law and Policy
courses.description: Development in the law, policy, and business of Internet-mediated communications and commerce; emphasis on impact on existing legal, regulatory, and economic models.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGR 310orCOMM 180orCOMM 271orMGMT 215

courses.title: Introduction to Science Writing and Communication
courses.description: Learn how to write science stories that are accurate, clear, and compelling.

courses.title: Telecommunications Management
courses.description: Introduction to basic principles of management as they apply in electronic media industries.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 180

courses.title: Magazine Writing
courses.description: Idea conception, writing, and editing of magazine stories.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 260W

courses.title: Photography for the Mass Media
courses.description: Development of an informed and critical approach to photocommunication; individual and team projects, seminars, and critiques.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Enforced Prerequisite at Enrollment:COMM 269

coursesTabContent.programIntro: This program integrates courses in visual arts and design, information sciences and technology, communications, and General Education electives.
curriculumDescription: Through your course work, you can enhance your ability to use creative thinking and critical reasoning to organize ideas and present them in a range of visual forms, scenarios, and narrative projects. You'll also have the opportunity to study in a collaborative format that will allow you to work with other students to further explore and apply what you're learning.

The Bachelor of Design in Digital Multimedia Design program requires you to complete a minimum of 120 credits.
Students can earn up to 6 COMM credits through the
credit-by-portfolio
process.
However, it is important for students to know that completing the credit-by-portfolio process does not guarantee that the credits will be awarded.

Choose 6 credits
of history of art, design, technology, and communications courses in consultation with an adviser.
Choose 12 credits
in related areas in consultation with an adviser.

courses.title: Introduction to Digital Art and Design Criticism
courses.description: An introduction to the language, aesthetics, and cultural impacts of digital art and design in contemporary society.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Basic Photography for Communications
courses.description: An introduction to digital photography, emphasizing camera skills, aesthetics, and storytelling.
courses.additionalInfo:
Note Basic Photography for Communications is a hands-on, skills-oriented, results-driven class that requires students to own a suitable mobile phone along with a computer and software. Please contact Will Yurman, instructor, atwhy1@psu.eduwith any questions or concerns.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Writing for Media
courses.description: The application of creativity to the practical concerns of narrative script and radio/television spot writing.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Enforced Prerequisite at Enrollment:ENGL 15andENGL 202
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: 2D Digital Arts & Computer Graphics
courses.description: Introduces 2D digital imaging techniques and concepts for the production of original art and design using graphics software.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Digital Multimedia Design Foundations
courses.description: This course introduces students to concepts, skills, language and principles of practice in art and design, communication, and information sciences.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Digital Multimedia Design Studio
courses.description: In this course students synthesize concepts, theories, and applications acquired in introductory courses and think critically about their professional objectives.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite DMD 100 and 9 credits from the following list: IST 140, IST 250, COMM 230W, COMM 215, DART 202, ART 211Y
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Digital Multimedia Design Capstone
courses.description: In this capstone, students develop portfolio projects by applying creative production concepts, tools, and approaches to a contemporary issue.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite DMD 100andDMD 300
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Foundations of Human-Centered Design and Development
courses.description: Examines the relationship between physical capabilities, cognitive and social models, and philosophical issues pertinent to human-centered analysis, design and development work.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Web Design and Development
courses.description: Introduction to how the World Wide Web utilizes emerging technologies. Students acquire a conceptual understanding of constructing websites.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Visual Studies
courses.description: Introduction to visual studies; pictorial space and the principles of visual organization.

courses.title: Introduction to Drawing
courses.description: Introductory experience in making of art through drawing media; designed for nonmajors seeking general overview of studio practice.

courses.title: Introduction to Media Effects
courses.description: Examination of individuals' selection, uses and perceptions of media and the effects of media on individuals' attitudes, beliefs, and behaviors.

courses.title: Survey of Electronic Media and Telecommunications
courses.description: The development of electronic media and telecommunications, emphasizing social, economic, political and global impact.

courses.title: Introduction to Telecommunications Technologies
courses.description: Students will evaluate content creation and distribution methods and demonstrate proficiency across emerging digital products and services.

courses.title: Idea Development and Media Writing
courses.description: Introduction to various modalities of idea development and written expression for media production.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Enforced Prerequisite at Enrollment:COMM 242orCOMM 282

courses.title: Principles of Strategic Communications
courses.description: Provides an overview of the various media and communications methods that comprise modern integrated marketing campaigns.

courses.title: Photography for the Mass Media
courses.description: Development of an informed and critical approach to photocommunication; individual and team projects, seminars, and critiques.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Enforced Prerequisite at Enrollment:COMM 269

courses.title: Internet Law and Policy
courses.description: Development in the law, policy, and business of Internet-mediated communications and commerce; emphasis on impact on existing legal, regulatory, and economic models.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGR 310orCOMM 180orCOMM 271orMGMT 215

courses.title: 3D Digital Art & Design Fundamentals
courses.description: Introduces 3D foundational skills for producing images, videos, objects, and interactive real-time virtual spaces with 3D software.

courses.title: Animation Fundamentals
courses.description: Introduces time-based animation fundamentals along with core skills and knowledge necessary for producing animated work.

courses.title: Web Design and Visual Web Development
courses.description: Introduces essential techniques and concepts of modern web design, focusing on how visual graphics and layout contribute to user experience.

courses.title: Digital Portfolio Elements
courses.description: An intermediate level studio course in which students develop digital art and design work that promotes creative thinking and problem-based learning in producing digital media projects to be included in their digital portfolio.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DART 202orDART 203orDART 204orDART 205orDART 206

courses.title: Portfolio Design and Professional Practices
courses.description: This course emphasizes the development of presentation skills for digital artists in audience/client interactions.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DART 300

courses.title: User Experience Design: Concepts and Principles
courses.description: Study foundational concepts and methodologies in User Experience (UX) design and thinking. The course will feature iterative design processes to employ basic management techniques in working with product stakeholders for digital planning practices.

courses.title: User Interface Design and Prototyping
courses.description: Apply knowledge in User Interface (UI) design and practice designing and prototyping compelling visual interfaces for multiple platforms - from websites to physical spaces to the nuanced interactions in mobile and wearable environments.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite GD 110

courses.title: Object-Oriented Design and Software Applications
courses.description: Introduction to object-oriented applications, including applications in an Object-Oriented Design (OOD) language or OOD languages.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242orCMPSC 221

courses.title: Usability Engineering
courses.description: This course addresses activities in the system development process that ensure usability. It considers the emerging concept of usability, requirements gathering and analysis, activity design, information design, interaction design, documentation design, user testing, and usability evaluation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 331

courses.title: Intermediate and Object-Oriented Application Development
courses.description: Intermediate application development including algorithms, data structures, and object-oriented concepts.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 140orCMPSC 121orIST 240

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio I
courses.description: Introductory design and development studio course for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242or permission of program

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The curriculum of this online degree program is designed to give you the tools to understand how incentives affect human behavior, markets, and economies so you can model real-life situations, effectively allocate resources, and map out the best outcomes.
curriculumDescription:
Economics is a social science that aims to understand and predict human behavior by combining a strong education in liberal arts with a thorough understanding of mathematics and computer science. The Bachelor of Arts in Economics program can offer you an excellent stepping stone to graduate or specialized studies, especially in economics or law school.
Entrance-to-Major Requirements
To change your major to economics, you must complete the following courses with a grade of C or better:
ECON 102
ECON 104
The Bachelor of Arts in Economics requires you to complete a minimum of 120 credits.
If you are a transfer student, the number of credits you must take will vary according to the courses that transfer into the economics program. Once you are admitted to the program, your assigned academic adviser can help you select the remaining required courses.
A student enrolled in this major must receive a grade of C or better in all courses required for the major.

For Supporting Courses, select 18 credits in economics 300- or 400-level with department approval, including at least 9 credits at the 400 level.
Additional 400-level courses are being developed. Please check with your adviser about their availability.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits

Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits

Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits

GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Statistical Foundations for Econometrics
courses.description: Basic statistical concepts used in economics. Topics include probability distributions, expectations, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation, and simple regression. Students who have completed ECON 306 may not schedule this course.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
courses.description: Allocation of resources and distribution of income within various market structures, with emphasis on analytical tools.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ECON 102
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of forces that determine the level of aggregate economic activity.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ECON 104
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Econometrics
courses.description: The implementation of statistical techniques to analyze data and address economic questions. Econometric results are produced and assessed.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ECON 106
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (select 18 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription:
For Supporting Courses, select 18 credits in economics 300- or 400-level with department approval, including at least 9 credits at the 400 level.
Additional 400-level courses are being developed. Please check with your adviser about their availability.

courses.title: Labor Economics
courses.description: Economic analysis of employment, earnings, and the labor market; labor relations; related government policies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102

courses.title: International Economics
courses.description: Why nations trade, barriers to trade, balance of payments adjustment and exchange rate determination, eurocurrency markets, and trade-related institutions.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102,ECON 104orECON 014

courses.title: Money and Banking
courses.description: Money, credit, commercial and central banking, financial intermediaries, treasury operations, monetary theory and policy, and foreign exchange. Students who have already taken ECON 451 may not schedule this course.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102orECON 104

courses.title: Decision Making and Strategy in Economics
courses.description: Development and application of the tools for decision making under uncertainty and for game theoretic analysis of economic problems.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302andECON 106orSCM 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Economics of Public Expenditures
courses.description: Analytic and policy aspects of public expenditure decisions; applications from areas of contemporary public interest.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 323

courses.title: Environmental Economics
courses.description: Environmental pollution, the market economy, and optimal resource allocation; alternative control procedures; levels of environmental protection and public policy.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 323

courses.title: Advanced International Trade Theory and Policy
courses.description: Causes/consequences of trade; effects of tariffs and quotas; strategic trade policy; political economy of trade restrictions and other topics.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 333

courses.title: International Finance and Open Economy Macroeconomics
courses.description: Trade balance movements, exchange rate determination; monetary and fiscal policies in open economies; international policy coordination; the world monetary system.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 304orECON 333

courses.title: Growth and Development
courses.description: Problems of capital formation, institutional considerations, theories of economic growth.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 304orECON 372

coursesTabContent.programIntro: This economics program’s courses are designed to teach you to think critically and analytically so you can make or recommend decisions, allocate resources, and solve complex issues.
curriculumDescription:
Economics is the social science that aims to understand human behavior not only by using psychology or sociology, but also by studying society through mathematics and statistics. A degree in economics can provide you with the knowledge necessary to view and describe society and organizations from an analytical perspective.
This economics degree can provide you with knowledge about mathematical models and statistical techniques and an understanding about how incentives affect human behavior, markets, and economies, so you can design solutions that utilize resources effectively and lead to the most optimal outcomes.
Entrance-to-Major Requirements
To change your major to economics, you must earn a C or better in the following courses:
ECON 102
ECON 104
The Bachelor of Science in Economics requires you to complete a minimum of 120 credits.
If you are a transfer student, the number of credits you must take will vary according to the courses that transfer into the economics program. Once you are admitted to the program, your assigned academic adviser can help you select the remaining required courses.
A student enrolled in this major must receive a grade of C or better in all courses required for the major.

Select 18 credits
in economics 300- or 400-level with department approval, including at least 9 credits at the 400 level

in Arts, Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences

in Quantification

from the department Supporting Courses list
.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Statistical Foundations for Econometrics
courses.description: Basic statistical concepts used in economics. Topics include probability distributions, expectations, estimation, hypothesis testing, correlation, and simple regression. Students who have completed ECON 306 may not schedule this course.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate Microeconomic Analysis
courses.description: Allocation of resources and distribution of income within various market structures, with emphasis on analytical tools.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ECON 102
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate Macroeconomic Analysis
courses.description: Analysis of forces that determine the level of aggregate economic activity.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ECON 104
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Econometrics
courses.description: The implementation of statistical techniques to analyze data and address economic questions. Econometric results are produced and assessed.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ECON 106
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Introduction to Spreadsheets and Databases
courses.description: Design, use, and programming of spreadsheets and data bases with applications from a range of disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo:
Note not currently offered online through World Campus.
Prerequisite 2 entrance units in mathematics

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 022or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Labor Economics
courses.description: Economic analysis of employment, earnings, and the labor market; labor relations; related government policies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102

courses.title: International Economics
courses.description: Why nations trade, barriers to trade, balance of payments adjustment and exchange rate determination, eurocurrency markets, and trade-related institutions.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102,ECON 104orECON 014

courses.title: Money and Banking
courses.description: Money, credit, commercial and central banking, financial intermediaries, treasury operations, monetary theory and policy, and foreign exchange. Students who have already taken ECON 451 may not schedule this course.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102orECON 104

courses.title: Decision Making and Strategy in Economics
courses.description: Development and application of the tools for decision making under uncertainty and for game theoretic analysis of economic problems.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302andECON 106orSCM 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Economics of Public Expenditures
courses.description: Analytic and policy aspects of public expenditure decisions; applications from areas of contemporary public interest.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 323

courses.title: Environmental Economics
courses.description: Environmental pollution, the market economy, and optimal resource allocation; alternative control procedures; levels of environmental protection and public policy.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 323

courses.title: Advanced International Trade Theory and Policy
courses.description: Causes/consequences of trade; effects of tariffs and quotas; strategic trade policy; political economy of trade restrictions and other topics.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 333

courses.title: International Finance and Open Economy Macroeconomics
courses.description: Trade balance movements, exchange rate determination; monetary and fiscal policies in open economies; international policy coordination; the world monetary system.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 304orECON 333

courses.title: Growth and Development
courses.description: Problems of capital formation, institutional considerations, theories of economic growth.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 304orECON 372

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
The Bachelor of Arts in Energy and Sustainability Policy (ESP) is designed for online students with various education experiences and professional goals. The prescribed courses focus on:
the energy industry and the domestic and global impact it has on the environment
foreign and domestic policy
corporate and community sustainability initiatives
curriculumDescription:
Please note that some courses in the ESP program require students to maintain a web presence, which may include creating a web page, blog posting, video sharing, and other internet participation. ESP students may be required to participate in online activities that are widely accessible to the public, including audiences outside of the Penn State community.
The course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 credits at Penn State to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.

Engaged Scholarship: Internships and Foreign Studies
Penn State was selected by the Carnegie Foundation for its 2015 Community Engagement Classification, an honor resulting from our commitment to providing students with at least one outside-the-classroom engagement opportunity that impacts our community. Every student in the ESP program takes part in this type of international study experience (EGEE 299) or domestic internship (EGEE 495). You will work with faculty to design a meaningful opportunity that complements your professional aspirations and busy schedule.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.

courses.title: Effective Speech
courses.description: Introduction to speech communication: formal speaking, group discussion, analysis and evaluation of messages.

courses.title: Introduction to Energy and Earth Sciences Economics
courses.description: Resource use decisions and their effect on local, national, and global development.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Energy Conservation for Environmental Protection
courses.description: Exposure to energy efficiency in day-to-day life to save money and energy, and thereby protect the environment.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Oil: International Evolution
courses.description: Survey of the commercial development of the world petroleum industry from various international, historical, business, and cultural perspectives.

courses.title: Energy in a Changing World
courses.description: Energy is in transition, with increased international energy demand and increasing environmental pressures. Energy transitions, approaches, and outcomes are addressed.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite EGEE 101orEGEE 102orCHEM 112

courses.title: Global Energy Enterprise
courses.description: Industry perspective on the resources, technologies, engineering approaches, and externalities involved in satisfying worldwide energy demand profitably and sustainably.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ECON 104andEGEE 102 andEGEE 120
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Energy and Sustainability in Society
courses.description: Provides the culminating experience for Energy and Sustainability Policy majors through an individualized inquiry-based capstone project in which students tackle the wicked problems of sustainability they see and experience in their own communities.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite To be taken only after all other courses have been successfully completed
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Energy and Sustainability in Contemporary Culture
courses.description: Critical evaluation of selected media (e.g., books, film) in contemporary culture on topics related to energy and sustainability.

courses.title: Orientation to Energy and Sustainability Policy
courses.description: Orientation to goals of the Energy and Sustainability Policy program and resources available to help students succeed.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Instruction and practice in writing expository prose that shows sensitivity to audience and purpose.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30) andfourth-semester standing
GWS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Environment and Society in a Changing World
courses.description: Introduction to the relationships between humans and the natural environment, in addition to the theories and methods that geographers employ in addressing them.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Energy Policy
courses.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite EBF 200andEGEE 120andPLSC 490
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Energy Policy
courses.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite EBF 200andEGEE 120andPLSC 490
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Human Dimensions of Global Warming
courses.description: Human dimensions of global environmental change: human causes; human adaptations; and policy implications of global warming.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (EARTH 2orGEOG 10orMETEO 3) andGEOG 30N
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: From Meteorology to Mitigation: Understanding Global Warming
courses.description: Examination of global warming and climate change: the basic science, projects, impacts, and approaches to mitigation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200orMATH 110orMATH 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: Policy Making and Evaluation

courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (PLSC 1 andPLSC 2)orPUBPL 304W
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introductory Meteorology
courses.description: Nontechnical treatment of fundamentals of modern meteorology and the effects of weather and climate.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The B.S. in Energy and Sustainability Policy (ESP) is a 120-credit online degree program that emphasizes sustainability principles, policy development, and energy production. Students in the B.S. program also choose supporting course work in focused areas closely related to the major.
curriculumDescription:
Prescribed course work includes such topics as:
energy sources, uses, and technologies
sustainability principles and practices
climate change
policy development and analysis
You will also select additional courses in energy and science; analysis and technology; business and management; and ethics, leadership, and communications.

Engaged Scholarship: Internships and Foreign Studies
Penn State was selected by the Carnegie Foundation for its 2015 Community Engagement Classification, an honor resulting from our commitment to providing students with at least one outside-the-classroom engagement opportunity that impacts our community. For ESP students, foreign studies (EGEE 299) or domestic internship (EGEE 495) provide opportunity for learning outside of the classroom. You will work with faculty to design a meaningful and appropriate experience, considering your prior work and travel, interests, and professional aspirations.

Supporting courses should be selected in consultation with an adviser.

in Energy and Science
Select 6 credits
in Analysis and Technology

in Business and Management

in Ethics, Leadership and Communication

coursesTabContent.programIntro: Your courses will focus on theoretical foundations as well as the accounting, supply chain management, and business skills needed for incorporating information technology into different systems to enhance or improve organizational performance.
curriculumDescription:
To earn the Bachelor of Science in Enterprise Technology Integration (ETI), you must complete a minimum of 124 credits:
91–92 credits required for the major
5–6 credits of electives
45 General Education credits (18 of these credits are included in the requirements for the major)
Students enrolled in this program will be required to complete at least one 300-hour internship. This can be accomplished by taking 1 credit of IST 495 or via credit by portfolio. Assistance with internship preparation is available through Penn State College of Information Sciences and Technology Career Services.
Entrance-to-Major Requirements
To gain admission to the College of Information Sciences and Technology, you must have earned three and a half units of high school mathematics (selected from any combination of algebra, geometry, and trigonometry or higher math courses) or you must meet one of the following equivalent college course work requirements by:
completing MATH 22 (College Algebra II and Analytic Geometry) or MATH 26 (Plane Trigonometry) OR a higher-level math course offered by Penn State, determined in consultation with your academic adviser
completing a trigonometry or higher-level course at another accredited institution with a grade of "C" or better
receiving sufficient scores on Advanced Placement calculus exams
Once you are admitted to the pre-major in the
College of Information Sciences and Technology
, you will work closely with your academic adviser to gain entrance to the enterprise technology integration major.
All prescribed courses must be completed with a grade of C or better.
All additional courses must be completed with a grade of C or better.

The degree also includes a requirement for a coherent application focus. Students must schedule a sequence of courses in a discipline related to ETI, including business, economics, human-computer interaction, and cybersecurity, in consultation with their adviser. Students can pick one of the tracks below or create a custom 4-course application focus.
Select 12 credits from below, with at least three (3) credits at the 400 level.
Select 12 credits from below or any CYBER course at the 300 or 400 level, with at least three (3) credits at the 400 level.

There is an option for a student to create a custom 4-course application focus sequence. It must be a coherent sequence of courses that provides context for the student in terms of ETI content. Students can select the custom application focus with approval from an academic adviser, and courses must be selected in consultation with an ETI teaching faculty member. Students may want to consider choosing courses that also fulfill US and/or IL requirements.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits

6 credits

9 credits

allSections.sectionDescription: All prescribed courses must be completed with a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or a higher math course or a satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Development and Documentation of Enterprise Web
courses.description: Students will draw upon their prior experience in databases, networks, and programming to understand how cloud-based infrastructure solutions are built, the possible choices an analyst will have, and the written communication needed in order to convey these design choices to others.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220andIST 256

courses.title: Information and Organizations
courses.description: Overview of organizational structures and functions. Includes information processing and analytic perspectives of organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220

courses.title: IT Project Management
courses.description: Exploration and application of the basic concepts, methodologies, and tools of project management in the field of information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220

courses.title: Fundamentals of Systems and Enterprise Integration
courses.description: Introductory course on integration of information technology into different venues, including the planning, development, and implementation of the integration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (C or better inETI 301andETI 302)and (C or better inIST 240orIST 242)

courses.title: Advanced Enterprise Integration: Technologies and Applications
courses.description: Advanced course on the integration of information technology into systems applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inETI 420

courses.title: Database Management and Administration
courses.description: A study of advanced topics in database management systems that are fundamental to effective administration of modern enterprise information systems.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 242

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140

courses.title: Programming for the Web
courses.description: This course will provide students with the knowledge and skills to create both basic and more dynamic web-based content pages and applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 250orIST 242orCMPSC 122orCMPSC 132

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor
Note Internships provide valuable experience for students; however, we recognize that situations vary and some students, due to work or other commitments, are unable to adjust their schedules. courses.description: Introduction to emerging issues, technology forecasting and analysis; overview of emerging issues and leading technologies in IST and how they impact information systems, users, the IT labor force and society.

courses.title: Enterprise Information Management and Storage Architecture

courses.title: International Business Operations
courses.description: A survey of the major aspects of international business environment and operations with an emphasis on the cultural dimension.

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts

courses.description: Covers terminology and important concepts related to marketing in the business environment. Domestic and international environments that impact marketing are included, with particular emphasis on the marketing environment, segmentation, positioning, and targeting.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030;ECON 102orECON 104;MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Prepares students both to understand the communications that surrounds them and to succeed in their own communication efforts. The course focuses specifically on analyzing verbal and visual texts (reading) as well as on producing such texts (writing), always in terms of rhetorical principles.

courses.title: Intermediate and Object-Oriented Application Development
courses.description: Intermediate application development including algorithms, data structures, and object-oriented concepts.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 140orCMPSC 121orIST 240

courses.title: Computer Systems Literacy
courses.description: This is an introductory university-level course in computer systems literacy. The history, architecture, and operation of computing systems and underlying computing theory are covered.

courses.title: Foundations of Human-Centered Design and Development
courses.description: Examines the relationship between physical capabilities, cognitive and social models, and philosophical issues pertinent to human-centered analysis, design and development work.

courses.title: Information, People, and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.

courses.title: Enterprise Analytics
courses.description: Explores topics including enterprise-level analytics, big data, and analytics case studies in health care, manufacturing, HR, and financial services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andETI 461

courses.title: Distributed Database Management Systems
courses.description: Focuses on the design and system issues related to distributed database systems.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 220andIST 242andETI 461

courses.title: Information Sciences and Technology Integration and Problem Solving
courses.description: Problem-based approach to technology integration by focusing on real-life problems faced by an organization.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202CorENGL 202Dand seventh-semester standing (this course is intended for seniors)
