courses.description: Introduction to object-oriented applications, including applications in an Object-Oriented Design (OOD) language or OOD languages.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242orCMPSC 221

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio II
courses.description: Second of two design and development studio courses for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242

courses.title: Distributed-Object Computing
courses.description: Introduction to distributed-object computing and its use in client/server and real-world computing applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311

courses.title: The Engineering of Complex Software Systems
courses.description: Introduction to the engineering of complex software systems, including software system specification, design and implementation, integration and test, and evolution.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311

allSections.sectionDescription: Select 12 credits from below or any CYBER course at the 300 or 400 level, with at least three (3) credits at the 400 level.

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.

courses.title: Overview of Information Security
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the overview of information security, including security architecture, access control, and internet secure applications.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 111,IST 110,CMPSC 101
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Cyber-Defense Studio
courses.description: This studio course teaches four basic hands-on cyber-defense skills: configuring a firewall, implementing a host-based intrusion detection software tool, using the Metasploit tool to do penetration testing, and implementing a network intrusion detection tool.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (CYBER 100 or CYBER 100S)andIST 140

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.

courses.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220and (SRA 221orCYBER 221)

courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.

courses.title: Development and Documentation of Enterprise Web
courses.description: Students will draw upon their prior experience in databases, networks, and programming to understand how cloud-based infrastructure solutions are built, the possible choices an analyst will have, and the written communication needed in order to convey these design choices to others.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220andIST 256

courses.title: Information and Organizations
courses.description: Overview of organizational structures and functions. Includes information processing and analytic perspectives of organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220

courses.title: IT Project Management
courses.description: Exploration and application of the basic concepts, methodologies, and tools of project management in the field of information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220

courses.description: Introductory course on integration of information technology into different venues, including the planning, development, and implementation of the integration.

courses.description: Advanced course on the integration of information technology into systems applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inETI 420

courses.description: A study of advanced topics in database management systems that are fundamental to effective administration of modern enterprise information systems.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 242

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140

courses.title: Programming for the Web
courses.description: This course will provide students with the knowledge and skills to create both basic and more dynamic web-based content pages and applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 250orIST 242orCMPSC 122orCMPSC 132

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The bachelor’s degree in finance courses provide a firm grounding in the principles of business, economics, and accounting — with an in-depth focus on issues and knowledge in finance and financial management.
curriculumDescription:
You will study all components of the field of finance, including investments, corporate finance, and financial markets. You’ll also develop a solid foundation in principles of finance, including capital management, investment and portfolio management, financial institutions, and personal finance.
Entrance-to-Major Requirements
To change your major to finance, you must earn at least 29.1 credits and a C or better in the following 5 entry-to-major courses:
ACCTG 211
ECON 102
ENGL 15 or ENGL 30
MATH 110 or MATH 140
SCM 200 or STAT 200 or equivalent
A Behrend campus dean's review is required for all students in order to enter the major directly as well as for all students who have earned 45 or more transferable credits.
A current Penn State student needs a grade point average of 2.0 or higher to enter the major. Transfer students require a minimum 2.0 cumulative grade point average to enter the major.
The Bachelor of Science in Finance degree requires students to complete a minimum of 120 credits.
The number of credits you will have to take will vary according to the courses you transfer into the degree program. Once you are admitted into the degree program, an assigned academic adviser will help you with remaining requirements; 21 of the 45 General Education credits are included in the requirements for the major.

1 credit
of electives. Consult your academic adviser when choosing an elective to fulfill this requirement.

Select 6 additional credits
from 400-level FIN courses, excluding FIN 494 and FIN 495.
Select 6 credits
from FIN or other business areas.

Select 15 credits
from any business major field or any non-business major course, except for all Health and Wellness (GHW) courses, any ENGL course below ENGL 15, and any MATH course below MATH 110. Students are encouraged to work with their adviser to identify the appropriate supporting courses.

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
Data-based decision-making is core to the success of businesses across all sectors. This bachelor of science degree can help you prepare for a rewarding career as data analyst by studying:
programming
calculus
statistics
information technology and information science
data analysis
communication
project management
curriculumDescription:
In addition, you will learn the four data analysis models:
Descriptive analytics — what happened
Diagnostic analytics — why it happened, including external factors
Predictive analytics — what will happen next
Prescriptive analytics — what should happen
Entrance-to-Major Requirements
To change your major to functional data analytics, successfully complete 4 entrance-to-major courses with a grade of C or better:
CMPSC 121
DA 101
MATH 110 or MATH 140
PSYCH 200 or STAT 200
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses.
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses.

Select one special interest concentration from the program-approved list of concentrations.
Select six credits from any major field or course, except STAT 100, MATH 200, MATH 201, any ENGL course below ENGL 15, any KINES (GHW) courses, and any MATH course below MATH 83.
Petitions for exceptions are available through the applicable program chair. The Supporting Course Requirements encourage students to develop a distinctive competency in a related field such as finance, program evaluation, or another program-approved area that will differentiate them upon graduation. This section also gives the students flexibility to explore course work outside of their discipline. Students are strongly encouraged to discuss their options with their academic adviser.
This concentration exposes students to the application of analytics in four domain areas: business, engineering, humanities and the social sciences, and science.

Financial analytics is the use of tools and processes to combine and analyze data sets to gain insights into the financial performance of your organization. Bringing together data from all your systems gives you a holistic view of your business and broader insights that help you to predict and improve performance.

Program evaluation is a systematic method for collecting, analyzing, and using information to answer questions about projects, policies, and programs, particularly about their effectiveness and efficiency.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits

9 credits

allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses.

courses.title: Effective Speech
courses.description: Introduction to speech communication: formal speaking, group discussion, analysis and evaluation of messages.

courses.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to foundational concepts that are used in the data analytics industry to understand and frame projects

courses.title: Descriptive Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to the core areas of descriptive analytics, where the main objective is to answer "what happened" in a project. Students will learn how to accurately describe the attributes of data variables available to them for their projects. Students will have the opportunity to work on real-life projects and cases throughout the course, learning the importance of communicating findings to different constituents.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (PSYCH 200orSTAT 200orSTAT 250orSCM 200) and (DA 101orDS 200)

courses.title: Diagnostic Analytics
courses.description: This course takes descriptive data a step further by examining the relationships between variables through root cause analysis. Students will learn current tools and techniques that allow analysts to explain why the patterns are observed in data and discover relationships between two or more attributes of the data.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DA 201WorDA 101

courses.title: Predictive Analytics
courses.description: Helps students learn to predict what will happen in future events based on historical data. Students will learn how to properly examine problem contexts to use the most appropriate method to develop the best predictive model as well as how to evaluate their results and interpret findings to users at different levels of an organization.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DA 301

courses.title: Data Ethics and Privacy
courses.description: Cultivates awareness of ethical, privacy, and security rules and standards to guide how to use and analyze data and communicate the findings. The course will emphasize ethics at various stages of data analytics, including the communication of the implications of data analysis to stakeholders, how data is collected and stored, as well as how it is analyzed and presented to different stakeholders.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DA 101

courses.title: Prescriptive Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to how data analytics assists in making decisions and advocating for a course of action. Helps students learn to develop a set of viable decision options, rank those decision options to create alternative courses of action, and achieve an optimal decision.

courses.title: Qualitative Analytics
courses.description: Offers an overview of data analytics techniques for non-numeric data (e.g., text, videos, or images). Students will explore methodological reasons for a qualitative rather than a quantitative approach, and the underlying challenges with this type of data, depending on the hypothesis or research question. A strong background in statistics is required for this course.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite DA 201W
Concurrent ENGL 202AorENGL 202BorENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courses.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone I
courses.description: This course allows students to demonstrate their ability to use industry or organization data to develop a descriptive, diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive analysis. This portion of the capstone addresses the understanding of the industry data, project scope, data journalism, and descriptive analysis.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite DA 302WandDA 305andMIS 447
Concurrent MGMT 409

courses.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone II
courses.description: This course continues the industry project (assigned in DA 475) and the remaining three-part analysis of organization-specific analysis (diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive).

courses.title: Data Visualization
courses.description: Presents techniques and software used for data visualization. Students will be introduced to complex data sets and learn how to present findings in interactive and innovative ways.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Simulations of Human Behavior
courses.description: Students will develop an understanding of the systems, processes, tools, and implications of this field.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits of programming and 3 credits of mathematics

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15or ENGL 15A or ENGL 15S or ENGL 15E orESL 15 orENGL 30H or ENGL 30T or ENGL 137H or CAS 137H)& and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140

courses.title: Project Management for Non-Business Majors
courses.description: Covers the technical and people skills related to project management within a variety of organizational structures. Students learn the tools and concepts needed to successfully balance schedule, budget, and scope while managing risk and resources during the project life cycle. Leadership and teamwork skills are emphasized and practiced in a hands-on approach.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 5th-semester standing

courses.title: Social Media Management and Analytics
courses.description: In-depth analysis of social media management, digital marketing, SEO/M, and analytics of current digital business practices. Presents an analysis of current issues in digital marketing and the tools needed to assess those issues.

courses.title: Data Warehousing
courses.description: Using case studies in various business domains, exercises, and projects, this course presents practical dimensional modeling techniques, extract/transformation/load (ETL) logic, ETL design considerations, and report generation. Key concepts related to data warehousing, including dimensional table characteristics, fact table characteristics and granularity, types of dimensions, types of fact tables, dimension attribute hierarchies, consolidated fact tables, slowly changing dimension techniques, and multivalued dimensions and weighting factors are covered in the course.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MIS 336or equivalent approved course

courses.title: Ethics
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic questions of ethics, the major currents in traditional ethical theory (virtue ethics, deontology, consequentialism), and more recent developments (e.g., care ethics).

courses.title: Introduction to R
courses.description: This course will introduce students to data computing fundamentals and a reproducible workflow using the R programming language and related tools. R is a powerful, open-source programming language used widely for applications in statistics and data science. Students will be expected to access, join, wrangle, clean, and visualize real data from various sources (e.g., CSV, HTML scraping, web URL, R packages).
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher

allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
courses.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110or prerequisite or concurrentMATH 140

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Prepares students both to understand the communications that surrounds them and to succeed in their own communication efforts. The course focuses specifically on analyzing verbal and visual texts (reading) as well as on producing such texts (writing), always in terms of rhetorical principles.

courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Theory and utilization of database management systems in organizations, including data modeling and applications development.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MIS 204orMIS 110orCMPSC 121orCMPSC 102

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics in Psychology
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the descriptive and inferential statistics commonly used in psychology, and to hypothesis testing as a method of scientific investigation. It also explores the ways in which the assumptions of statistical tests place constraints on experimental design and, conversely, how the design of experiments can dictate the statistical test appropriate for data analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andMATH 21

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

The Supporting Course Requirements encourage students to develop a distinctive competency in a related field such as finance, program evaluation, or another program-approved area that will differentiate them upon graduation. This section also gives the students flexibility to explore course work outside of their discipline. Students are strongly encouraged to discuss their options with their academic adviser.
This concentration exposes students to the application of analytics in four domain areas: business, engineering, humanities and the social sciences, and science.

courses.title: Analytics in Business
courses.description: Introduction to the use of analytics in business contexts, including data-driven decision-making and performance optimization in areas such as finance, management information systems, marketing, international business, accounting, and economics.

courses.title: Analytics in Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to the application of analytics in engineering, with a focus on system optimization, process improvement, and predictive modeling in engineering problems.

courses.title: Analytics in Science
courses.description: Introduction to the use of analytics in natural sciences, covering topics like experimental data analysis, statistical modeling, and simulation in scientific research.

courses.title: Analytics in Humanities and the Social Sciences
courses.description: Introduction to the application of analytics in humanities and social sciences, including text analysis, thematic and content analysis, statistical modeling, regression analysis, media analytics, program evaluation, trend analysis, text mining, demography, ethnography, simulation, and the interpretation of cultural data in fields such as education, psychology, sociology, political science, communication, cultural studies, history, and language arts.

allSections.sectionDescription: Financial analytics is the use of tools and processes to combine and analyze data sets to gain insights into the financial performance of your organization. Bringing together data from all your systems gives you a holistic view of your business and broader insights that help you to predict and improve performance.

courses.title: Corporation Finance
courses.description: Nature of finance function; risk and return concepts; working capital; dividend policies; mergers; security markets; acquisition and management of corporate capital; analysis of operations; forecasting capital requirements; raising capital; and planning profits. Available to baccalaureate students only.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)andACCTG 211and (ECON 102orECON 104) and (SCM 200orSTAT 200)

courses.title: Intermediate Financial Modeling
courses.description: The course focuses primarily on the development of spreadsheet applications and the use of the case method to apply decision-making procedures to real-world problems in finance areas.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite FIN 301

courses.title: Investment and Portfolio Analysis
courses.description: Investment and risk, types of security investments, sources of investment information, the broker, the stock market, portfolio management.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite FIN 301
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Use Cases in Financial Analytics
courses.description: 6–10 case studies demonstrating types of studies in financial analytics

allSections.sectionDescription: Program evaluation is a systematic method for collecting, analyzing, and using information to answer questions about projects, policies, and programs, particularly about their effectiveness and efficiency.

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.

courses.title: Basic Research Methods in Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to methods of psychological research, with special attention to hypothesis formation and testing, threats to validity, and data presentation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andPSYCH 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Principles of Measurement
courses.description: An introductory course about properties of test scores such as reliability and validity. In addition, the course focuses on the construction and evaluation of measurement instruments used in educational and psychological settings and may include topics such as test development, score reporting, and interpretation. Basic statistics are introduced throughout the course to interpret the psychometric properties of scores.

courses.title: Program Evaluation
courses.description: Identify and understand the normative assumptions specific to organizations about their basic program design, implementation, and assessment processes.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (PSYCH 100orSOC 1) and (PSYCH 200orSTAT 200) andPSYCH 301W

allSections.sectionDescription:
Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

courseSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses.

courses.title: Effective Speech
courses.description: Introduction to speech communication: formal speaking, group discussion, analysis and evaluation of messages.

courses.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to foundational concepts that are used in the data analytics industry to understand and frame projects

courses.title: Descriptive Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to the core areas of descriptive analytics, where the main objective is to answer "what happened" in a project. Students will learn how to accurately describe the attributes of data variables available to them for their projects. Students will have the opportunity to work on real-life projects and cases throughout the course, learning the importance of communicating findings to different constituents.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (PSYCH 200orSTAT 200orSTAT 250orSCM 200) and (DA 101orDS 200)

courses.title: Diagnostic Analytics
courses.description: This course takes descriptive data a step further by examining the relationships between variables through root cause analysis. Students will learn current tools and techniques that allow analysts to explain why the patterns are observed in data and discover relationships between two or more attributes of the data.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DA 201WorDA 101

courses.title: Predictive Analytics
courses.description: Helps students learn to predict what will happen in future events based on historical data. Students will learn how to properly examine problem contexts to use the most appropriate method to develop the best predictive model as well as how to evaluate their results and interpret findings to users at different levels of an organization.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DA 301

courses.title: Data Ethics and Privacy
courses.description: Cultivates awareness of ethical, privacy, and security rules and standards to guide how to use and analyze data and communicate the findings. The course will emphasize ethics at various stages of data analytics, including the communication of the implications of data analysis to stakeholders, how data is collected and stored, as well as how it is analyzed and presented to different stakeholders.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite DA 101

courses.title: Prescriptive Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to how data analytics assists in making decisions and advocating for a course of action. Helps students learn to develop a set of viable decision options, rank those decision options to create alternative courses of action, and achieve an optimal decision.

courses.title: Qualitative Analytics
courses.description: Offers an overview of data analytics techniques for non-numeric data (e.g., text, videos, or images). Students will explore methodological reasons for a qualitative rather than a quantitative approach, and the underlying challenges with this type of data, depending on the hypothesis or research question. A strong background in statistics is required for this course.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite DA 201W
Concurrent ENGL 202AorENGL 202BorENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courses.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone I
courses.description: This course allows students to demonstrate their ability to use industry or organization data to develop a descriptive, diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive analysis. This portion of the capstone addresses the understanding of the industry data, project scope, data journalism, and descriptive analysis.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite DA 302WandDA 305andMIS 447
Concurrent MGMT 409

courses.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone II
courses.description: This course continues the industry project (assigned in DA 475) and the remaining three-part analysis of organization-specific analysis (diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive).

courses.title: Data Visualization
courses.description: Presents techniques and software used for data visualization. Students will be introduced to complex data sets and learn how to present findings in interactive and innovative ways.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Simulations of Human Behavior
courses.description: Students will develop an understanding of the systems, processes, tools, and implications of this field.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits of programming and 3 credits of mathematics

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15or ENGL 15A or ENGL 15S or ENGL 15E orESL 15 orENGL 30H or ENGL 30T or ENGL 137H or CAS 137H)& and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140

courses.title: Project Management for Non-Business Majors
courses.description: Covers the technical and people skills related to project management within a variety of organizational structures. Students learn the tools and concepts needed to successfully balance schedule, budget, and scope while managing risk and resources during the project life cycle. Leadership and teamwork skills are emphasized and practiced in a hands-on approach.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 5th-semester standing

courses.title: Social Media Management and Analytics
courses.description: In-depth analysis of social media management, digital marketing, SEO/M, and analytics of current digital business practices. Presents an analysis of current issues in digital marketing and the tools needed to assess those issues.

courses.title: Data Warehousing
courses.description: Using case studies in various business domains, exercises, and projects, this course presents practical dimensional modeling techniques, extract/transformation/load (ETL) logic, ETL design considerations, and report generation. Key concepts related to data warehousing, including dimensional table characteristics, fact table characteristics and granularity, types of dimensions, types of fact tables, dimension attribute hierarchies, consolidated fact tables, slowly changing dimension techniques, and multivalued dimensions and weighting factors are covered in the course.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MIS 336or equivalent approved course

courses.title: Ethics
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic questions of ethics, the major currents in traditional ethical theory (virtue ethics, deontology, consequentialism), and more recent developments (e.g., care ethics).

courses.title: Introduction to R
courses.description: This course will introduce students to data computing fundamentals and a reproducible workflow using the R programming language and related tools. R is a powerful, open-source programming language used widely for applications in statistics and data science. Students will be expected to access, join, wrangle, clean, and visualize real data from various sources (e.g., CSV, HTML scraping, web URL, R packages).
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher

courseSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
courses.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110or prerequisite or concurrentMATH 140

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Prepares students both to understand the communications that surrounds them and to succeed in their own communication efforts. The course focuses specifically on analyzing verbal and visual texts (reading) as well as on producing such texts (writing), always in terms of rhetorical principles.

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 022or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Theory and utilization of database management systems in organizations, including data modeling and applications development.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MIS 204orMIS 110orCMPSC 121orCMPSC 102

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics in Psychology
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the descriptive and inferential statistics commonly used in psychology, and to hypothesis testing as a method of scientific investigation. It also explores the ways in which the assumptions of statistical tests place constraints on experimental design and, conversely, how the design of experiments can dictate the statistical test appropriate for data analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andMATH 21

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

courseSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (18–22 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription:
Select one special interest concentration from the program-approved list of concentrations.
Select six credits from any major field or course, except STAT 100, MATH 200, MATH 201, any ENGL course below ENGL 15, any KINES (GHW) courses, and any MATH course below MATH 83.
Petitions for exceptions are available through the applicable program chair. coursesTabContent.programIntro:
Our health policy and administration curriculum blends courses from several topic areas that can help you develop the expertise you will need to contribute to improvements in the health care system:
health sciences
business administration
liberal arts
curriculumDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Health Policy and Administration (HPA) is a 120-credit program that offers a solid foundation in the management, business, and policy aspects of health care.

At least 9 credits must be at the 400 level.
Select from University-wide offerings in consultation with adviser.
View the full department list
Please note that not all supporting courses on the department's list are available to online learners. Students can choose electives in consultation with their adviser.

General Education (45 credits)
12 credits are included in the requirements for the major.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.
Students can choose electives in consultation with their adviser.

Please note: Among the above degree requirements, you must incorporate at least 3 credits in U.S. cultures, 3 credits in international (IL) cultures, and 3 credits in Writing Across the Curriculum courses. The above course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.
courses.additionalInfo: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Introduction to Health Services Organization
courses.description: Examination of the social, political, historic, and scientific factors in the development and organization of health services.

courses.title: An Introduction to Data in the Health Care System
courses.description: This course examines the broad topic of data and health care decisions, particularly how to be an astute consumer of data about health, the health care system, and health policy.

courses.title: Health Care Payment
courses.description: This course covers basic concepts and issues related to health insurance and payment for health care providers.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102orHPA 101

courses.title: Financial Decisions in Health Care Organizations
courses.description: An introduction to financial and economic information to make decisions in health care organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 210

courses.title: Health Services Policy Issues
courses.description: Analysis of major issues in health services delivery in hospitals, medical practice, public health, mental health, and health professional education.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102orHPA 101orPLSC 001

courses.title: Health Care and Medical Needs
courses.description: Health care from an individual, family, and community standpoint illustrated with specific diseases and health problems.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite BBH 101orBISC 004orBIOL 141orBIOL 161
Concurrent HPA 101

courses.title: Population Health and Health Care
courses.description: This course covers fundamental theories, concepts, issues, and strategies related to a population health approach to health and health services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 101

courses.title: Health Systems Management
courses.description: Introduction to and analysis of managerial roles and practices in health service organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (HPA 211orACCTG 212) andHPA 101

courses.title: Professional Development in Health Policy and Administration
courses.description: Development of personal understanding and professional skills to prepare students for future employment or study in health policy and administration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 101

courses.title: Field Experience in Health Policy and Administration
courses.description: Professional field experience providing opportunities to apply skills and knowledge in health care setting.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite HPA 301,HPA 310,HPA 332,HPA 390W
Full-Time Equivalent Course Full-time equivalent (FTE) classes have been approved to be offered as full time regardless of the number of credits the class is worth.

courses.title: Strategic Planning and Marketing for Health Services
courses.description: Introduction to principles and methods of strategic planning and marketing.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 395

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Introduction to Spreadsheets and Databases
courses.description: Design, use, and programming of spreadsheets and data bases with applications from a range of disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo:
Note not currently offered online through World Campus.
Prerequisite 2 entrance units in mathematics

courses.title: Introduction to Business Information Systems
courses.description: Provides an overview of the role of information systems in business process design; the current technologies used for obtaining, storing, securing, and communicating information in support of operations and decision-making within a business organization; as well as the concepts and principles for developing and using popular spreadsheet and database tools.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 021or higher.
GQ This course can be used to satisfy the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.title: Health Care Leadership
courses.description: This course provides an opportunity to students to learn about the challenges of leadership in health care.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 301orHPA 311orHPA 332

courses.title: Culturally Competent Health Services for Diverse Populations
courses.description: This course examines the broad concept of diversity and its impact on health care, particularly on rendering services to patients from diverse groups and about the challenges health care professionals face serving diverse populations. Diversity includes many factors, such as age, ethnicity, race, religion, physical and mental disability, class, gender, and sexual orientation. To eradicate health disparities and improve health outcomes, students will explore effective and culturally appropriate strategies and interventions to deliver health care to diverse health care consumers.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 311

courses.title: Principles of Epidemiology
courses.description: Theory of epidemiology and significant case studies. Potential application to health care.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (BBH 310orBIOL 230WorHPA 311) and (STAT 200orSTAT 250)
Note This course is typically offered asBBH 440

courses.title: Long-Term Care Management
courses.description: Management and policy issues for institutional, community, and home settings for chronic care services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Human Resource Management in Health Care Organizations
courses.description: Foundations of human resource management applied to health care organizations, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, and community health organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Health Care Quality
courses.description: This course covers the basic principles and techniques of quality management in health care, including the definition, measurement, and uses of data for improving the quality of health and health services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Health Systems Management
courses.description: Introduction to and analysis of managerial roles and practices in health service organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (HPA 211orACCTG 212) andHPA 101

courses.title: Professional Development in Health Policy and Administration
courses.description: Development of personal understanding and professional skills to prepare students for future employment or study in health policy and administration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 101

courses.title: Field Experience in Health Policy and Administration
courses.description: Professional field experience providing opportunities to apply skills and knowledge in health care setting.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite HPA 301,HPA 310,HPA 332,HPA 390W
Full-Time Equivalent Course Full-time equivalent (FTE) classes have been approved to be offered as full time regardless of the number of credits the class is worth.

courses.title: Strategic Planning and Marketing for Health Services
courses.description: Introduction to principles and methods of strategic planning and marketing.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 395

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Introduction to Spreadsheets and Databases
courses.description: Design, use, and programming of spreadsheets and data bases with applications from a range of disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo:
Note not currently offered online through World Campus.
Prerequisite 2 entrance units in mathematics

courses.title: Introduction to Business Information Systems
courses.description: Provides an overview of the role of information systems in business process design; the current technologies used for obtaining, storing, securing, and communicating information in support of operations and decision-making within a business organization; as well as the concepts and principles for developing and using popular spreadsheet and database tools.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 021or higher.
GQ This course can be used to satisfy the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.title: Health Care Leadership
courses.description: This course provides an opportunity to students to learn about the challenges of leadership in health care.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 301orHPA 311orHPA 332

courses.title: Culturally Competent Health Services for Diverse Populations
courses.description: This course examines the broad concept of diversity and its impact on health care, particularly on rendering services to patients from diverse groups and about the challenges health care professionals face serving diverse populations. Diversity includes many factors, such as age, ethnicity, race, religion, physical and mental disability, class, gender, and sexual orientation. To eradicate health disparities and improve health outcomes, students will explore effective and culturally appropriate strategies and interventions to deliver health care to diverse health care consumers.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 311

courses.title: Principles of Epidemiology
courses.description: Theory of epidemiology and significant case studies. Potential application to health care.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (BBH 310orBIOL 230WorHPA 311) and (STAT 200orSTAT 250)
Note This course is typically offered asBBH 440

courses.title: Long-Term Care Management
courses.description: Management and policy issues for institutional, community, and home settings for chronic care services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Human Resource Management in Health Care Organizations
courses.description: Foundations of human resource management applied to health care organizations, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, and community health organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Health Care Quality
courses.description: This course covers the basic principles and techniques of quality management in health care, including the definition, measurement, and uses of data for improving the quality of health and health services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HPA 332

courseSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (30 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription:
At least 9 credits must be at the 400 level.
Select from University-wide offerings in consultation with adviser.
View the full department list

general education requirements
.
Students can choose electives in consultation with their adviser.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: A Penn State history degree can help you understand history by gaining a deep knowledge of culture, religion, art, politics, and war. Students in this program can develop skills in writing, reading, primary and secondary source analysis, chronological reasoning, and understanding complex causality.
curriculumDescription: The Bachelor of Arts in History requires you to complete a minimum of 123 credits.
A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.
A student enrolled in these courses must receive a grade of C or better.

allSections.sectionDescription: A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar
courses.description: Involves a thematic or topical investigation with an emphasis on historical criticism and analysis; students will pursue the study of one historical topic in detail in this writing intensive course.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 4th semester standing

allSections.sectionDescription: A student enrolled in these courses must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: American Civilization to 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from its colonial beginnings through the Civil War and Reconstruction.

courses.title: American Civilization Since 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from the emergence of urban-industrial society in the late nineteenth century to the present.

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (27 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: A student enrolled in these courses must receive a grade of C or better.

Select 12 credits at the 100–200 level, one course from each of the following field categories:
European History
United States History
Global History
Pre-Modern History
Courses that appear in two categories (such as HIST 107) cannot be double-counted to be applied to two field categories. However, the student may choose to which category to apply the course.

courses.title: Medieval Europe
courses.description: Covers the development of political, judicial, and diplomatic institutions; the role of religion as a significant element of medieval society; the development of royal houses; and changes in economic and social life of medieval Europe.

courses.title: History of Modern Europe Since 1789
courses.description: Political, social, and ideological developments; origin and impact of two World Wars; totalitarianism and democracy; changing role in the world.

courses.title: The World at War: 1914–1918
courses.description: Explores the military and political elements of World War I along with its profound impact on societies; topics include battle dynamics, state policies, and life on the home front — labor unrest, food insecurity, welfare efforts, and refugees.

courses.title: The World at War: 1939–1945
courses.description: In-depth study of the origins and conduct of World War II. Political and economic aspects as well as military.

courses.title: Introduction to U.S. Environmental History
courses.description: Explores changing relationships between humans and the natural world, while examining American landscape, environmental activism, and the development of ideas about nature. Major themes include the natural context of American history and the socially constructed and historically contingent knowledge about nature.

courses.title: Introduction to U.S. Food History
courses.description: Analyzes the history of agriculture and food production in the U.S., examining consumption patterns, the food industry, marketing, and regulation. Also explores the impact of food systems on human well-being and addresses issues of sustainability, productivity, social effects, and environmental impacts.

courses.title: Women in United States History
courses.description: Focuses on key historical developments in women’s history, including actual experiences as members of a class, a race, and an ethnic community; the progress women have made as individuals, workers, and citizens; as well as the opposition they have faced.

courses.title: Introduction to the Civil War Era, 1848 through 1877
courses.description: Survey of the causes and consequences of America's deadliest conflict, the Civil War, from the end of the U.S.-Mexican War in 1848 through the end of Reconstruction in 1877.

courses.title: History of Science I
courses.description: Surveys the history of science and scientific inquiry on a global scale from the Neolithic period to the 19th century.

courses.title: Islamic States, Societies, and Cultures c. 600-1500
courses.description: Introduces students to the history and culture of the Islamic world; develops a historical framework for understanding developments in religious and legal thought and practice, science, medicine, and technology, philosophy, and the arts.

courses.title: Latin American since 1820
courses.description: Examines the history of modern Latin America, including the geographic and political development of the region, the development of various economic models, and the widespread extraction of labor focusing on African slavery and Indigenous exploitation.

courses.title: Introduction to the Middle East
courses.description: Origins of Islamic civilization; expansion of Islam; the Ottoman Empire; the Middle East since 1918.

courses.title: Society and Culture in the Pacific War
courses.description: Looks at the origins, nature, and consequences of World War II in the Pacific; assesses different nations, political movements, ideologies, and empires that clashed across Asia-Pacific from 1931 to 1945.

courses.title: Modern Iran
courses.description: Surveys modern Iranian history from the 19th century to the present day, analyzing significant events, policies, and revolutions in local, regional, and global contexts. Students learn key concepts, make comparisons, and understand the broader historical trends of the 20th century.

courses.title: Modern Iran
courses.description: Surveys modern Iranian history from the 19th century to the present day, analyzing significant events, policies, and revolutions in local, regional, and global contexts. Students learn key concepts, make comparisons, and understand the broader historical trends of the 20th century.

courses.title: History of Science I
courses.description: Surveys the history of science and scientific inquiry on a global scale from the Neolithic period to the 19th century.

courses.title: The Roman Republic and Empire
courses.description: History of the Roman Republic and Empire from the origins of Rome to the disintegration of the Empire.

courses.title: Medieval Europe
courses.description: Covers the development of political, judicial, and diplomatic institutions; the role of religion as a significant element of medieval society; the development of royal houses; and changes in economic and social life of medieval Europe.

courses.title: Islamic States, Societies, and Cultures c. 600-1500
courses.description: Introduces students to the history and culture of the Islamic world; develops a historical framework for understanding developments in religious and legal thought and practice, science, medicine, and technology, philosophy, and the arts.

allSections.sectionDescription: Select an additional 100–400 level history course from any other category or

courses.title: History of Madness, Mental Illness, and Psychiatry
courses.description: Examines the ideas that have shaped European and American perceptions of madness, insanity, and mental illness; the changing experiences of those afflicted; the development of those professions designed to look after those deemed mad, insane, and mentally ill; and the social and cultural assumptions behind treatments, policies, and public opinions.

allSections.sectionDescription: At least one 400-level course should be in Global History.

courses.title: The Holocaust
courses.description: In-depth study of the history of the Holocaust in Europe that puts special emphasis on primary sources.

courses.title: Revolutionary America, 1753–1783
courses.description: Explores the forces in Great Britain and America that caused withdrawal of thirteen colonies from the British Empire and the Revolutionary War.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HIST 020, 3 additional credits in history

courses.title: Recent American History
courses.description: Contemporary economic, social, and political aspects of the United States and its role as a world power since 1945.

courses.title: Constitutional History since 1877
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the Constitutional developments from laissez-faire to the welfare state; imperialism, war, internationalism; the contemporary court, civil liberties, and civil rights.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Prerequisites:HIST 020orHIST 021, plus 3 additional credits in history or political science.

courses.title: American Environmental History
courses.description: The history of the ways Americans have used and thought about the environment since 1500.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courses.title: The Contemporary Middle East
courses.description: Focuses on the political, economic, and social changes in Turkey, Iran, Israel, and the Arab countries in the twentieth century; explores the Arab-Israeli conflict.
courses.additionalInfo: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

courses.title: History of Imperialism and Nationalism in Africa
courses.description: Theories and types of imperialism; varied patterns of colonial administration; initial African responses; nationalism; decolonization and independence.
courses.additionalInfo: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

courses.title: China in Revolution
courses.description: Explores the complex social and cultural history of modern China from 1900 to the present, including the formation of the modern nation-state, the development of communism, and the relationship between elite and popular culture.
courses.additionalInfo: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: Study a range of human services and diverse populations to gain an understanding of human development across the life span. You can learn how people change in response to their surroundings — within families, schools, communities, and the workplace. And you will explore how evidence-based interventions improve lives.
curriculumDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Human Development and Family Studies, Life Span Human Services option, is a 120-credit program. A grade of C or better is required in any HDFS course taken to satisfy the degree requirements. Consultation with your World Campus academic adviser to help you navigate your completion of this degree is strongly recommended.

You will study how family relationships, peers, social institutions (e.g., schools, work environments), income, religion, cultural background, and government policies all affect an individual's development and how interventions in these settings can facilitate growth and reduce problems in development. You will also investigate moral, ethical, and legal issues you will face as a professional, and learn to evaluate alternative approaches to promoting optimal development.

Human Development Courses (9 credits)
Select 6 credits from 300- or 400-level HDFS courses and select 3 credits from the following list of courses:

Select 12 credits (minimum of 6 credits at the 400 level) in consultation with your adviser from University-wide offerings that develop competency in the option (a grade of C or better is required in any HDFS course taken to satisfy this requirement).

Human Development Courses (9 credits)

courses.title: Infant Development
courses.description: Conceptual analysis, assessment, and empirical investigation of normal and deviant development, prenatal through first two years of life.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (HDFS 229orPSYCH 212) andHDFS 312W

courses.title: Advanced Child Development
courses.description: Processes of development during childhood from birth to adolescence. Emphasis on theory, method, and empirical research.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (HDFS 229orPSYCH 212) andHDFS 312W

courses.title: Developmental Transition to Adulthood
courses.description: Conceptual analysis and empirical investigation of interrelationships between developmental processes during the period of pubertal growth.

courses.title: Development throughout Adulthood
courses.description: Processes of development and change of behavior from early adulthood through old age, emphasizing theory, method, and empirical research.

courses.description: Implementation of internship projects or scholarly paper.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite or concurrent HDFS 495A

coursesTabContent.programIntro: Courses focus on developing theoretical foundations and real-world skills needed to incorporate information technology into different systems to improve system performance. You’ll study the frameworks needed to use information technology, as well as application-oriented experiences and skills.
curriculumDescription:
To earn the Bachelor of Science in Information Sciences and Technology degree program, you must complete a minimum 125 credits.
84 credits required for the major
26 prescribed credits
13 additional credits
21 supporting courses and related areas credits
24 option credits (Design and Development)
8 credits of electives
45 General Education credits (12 of these credits are included in the requirements for the major)
Entrance-to-Major Requirements
To change your major to IST, you must have earned at least 27.5 credits with a cumulative grade point average of 2.0 and a C or better in the following courses:
IST 110,
IST 140 (or equivalent CMPSC 101 or CMPSC 121),
IST 210,
and IST 220.
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses except STAT 200.
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses.

Emerging Issues and Technologies (3 credits):
Please consult your adviser to learn about additional options for this course requirement.
Foreign Language (12 credits):
Attainment of third-level proficiency in a single foreign language. Proficiency must be demonstrated by either examination or course work.
International Courses in Foreign Cultures (6 credits):
Select 6 credits in international courses in foreign culture from University-approved list (semesters: 5–8).

Prescribed Courses for the Design and Development Option (6 credits)
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses for the option.
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all studio courses for the option.
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses for the option.
Select 9 credits from College-approved list in consultation with an adviser.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses except STAT 200.

courses.title: Information and Organizations
courses.description: Overview of organizational structures and functions. Includes information processing and analytic perspectives of organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 210andIST 220

courses.title: Foundations of Human-Centered Design
courses.description: Interdisciplinary survey of topics and methods related to the human-centered design use and usability of information systems.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 240orIST 242

courses.title: Information, People, and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140

courses.title: Information Sciences and Technology Integration and Problem Solving
courses.description: Problem-based approach to technology integration by focusing on real-life problems faced by an organization.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202CorENGL 202Dand seventh-semester standing (this course is intended for seniors)

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor
Note Internships provide valuable experience for students; however, we recognize that situations vary and some students, due to work or other commitments, are unable to adjust their schedules. You are encouraged to contact your adviser to make arrangements for suitable activities in lieu of an internship.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development
courses.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level of Math 21 in the mathematics placement test.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 022or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (21 credits)

Emerging Issues and Technologies (3 credits):

Prescribed Courses for the Design and Development Option (6 credits)
Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses for the option.

courses.title: Object-Oriented Design and Software Applications
courses.description: Introduction to object-oriented applications, including applications in an Object-Oriented Design (OOD) language or OOD languages.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242orCMPSC 221

courses.title: Intermediate and Object-Oriented Application Development
courses.description: Intermediate application development including algorithms, data structures, and object-oriented concepts.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 140orCMPSC 121orIST 240

allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all studio courses for the option.

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio I
courses.description: Introductory design and development studio course for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242or permission of program

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio II
courses.description: Second of two design and development studio courses for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311or permission of program

allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses for the option.

courses.title: Distributed-Object Computing
courses.description: Introduction to distributed-object computing and its use in client/server and real-world computing applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311

courses.title: The Engineering of Complex Software Systems
courses.description: Introduction to the engineering of complex software systems, including software system specification, design and implementation, integration and test, and evolution.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311

allSections.sectionDescription: Courses chosen in consultation with an adviser.

courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inIST 242or permission of program

courses.title: Application Development Design Studio II
courses.description: Second of two design and development studio courses for IST and SRA students.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311or permission of program

courseSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses for the option.

courses.title: Distributed-Object Computing
courses.description: Introduction to distributed-object computing and its use in client/server and real-world computing applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311

courses.title: The Engineering of Complex Software Systems
courses.description: Introduction to the engineering of complex software systems, including software system specification, design and implementation, integration and test, and evolution.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite A grade of C or better inHCDD 311
