coursesTabContent.programIntro:
This program combines the content, theories, and methodologies of the social sciences and general education courses. The course work is grounded in the liberal arts and draws on core social science disciplines of:
anthropology
communication arts and sciences
economics
political science
psychology
sociology
curriculumDescription: To earn the Bachelor of Science in Integrated Social Sciences degree, you must successfully complete a minimum of 120 credits. Students will develop a final capstone portfolio.

The Bachelor of Science in Integrated Social Sciences curriculum is unique, so you must work closely with your adviser before choosing courses. This list is a reference of the course disciplines that may count toward this degree. A grade of C or better is required for all courses in the major.
Select 6–8 credits in quantification from MATH, CMPSC, IST, PHIL, ACCT, or STAT in consultation with your adviser.
Select 3–4 credits in statistics from the following:
Select 3–4 credits in research methods from the following:

In consultation with your adviser, select 30 credits from social science courses in the following areas: ANTH, CAS, ECON, PLSC, PSYCH, or SOC. At least 15 of these credits should be at the 400 level, with 9 credits from one discipline and 6 credits from a second discipline.

courses.title: Experiential Learning Portfolio
courses.description: Students will learn how to assemble a portfolio that reflects their progress, knowledge, and insight into college-level study.

courses.title: Independent Studies
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

allSections.sectionDescription: Select 6–8 credits in quantification from MATH, CMPSC, IST, PHIL, ACCT, or STAT in consultation with your adviser.
Select 3–4 credits in statistics from the following:

courses.title: Quantitative Political Analysis
courses.description: Data analysis and statistical applications in political research, including data processing, inferential statistics, contingency analysis, correlation and regression, and multivariate analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

courses.title: Elementary Statistics in Psychology
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the descriptive and inferential statistics commonly used in psychology, and to hypothesis testing as a method of scientific investigation. It also explores the ways in which the assumptions of statistical tests place constraints on experimental design and, conversely, how the design of experiments can dictate the statistical test appropriate for data analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andMATH 21

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive statistics, frequency distributions, probability, binomial and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.

allSections.sectionDescription: Select 3 credits in ethics from the following:

courses.title: Ethics
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic questions of ethics, the major currents in traditional ethical theory (virtue ethics, deontology, consequentialism), and more recent developments (e.g., care ethics).

courses.title: Ethics
courses.description: Focuses on ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100or 5th semester standing or 3 other credits of LHR

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

allSections.sectionDescription: Select 3–4 credits in research methods from the following:

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: An understanding of both qualitative research methods and the theoretical frameworks that inform qualitative inquiry. Additionally, this course focuses on tools for data collection such as individual and focus-group interviewing and observing and recording interaction. This course provides practical experience for students in collecting and analyzing qualitative data with and without the use of technology and examines particular difficulties in the interpretation and reporting of qualitative findings. Qualitative Research Methods is course that bridges disciplinary boundaries and is useful to any student who will be investigating human interaction.

courses.title: Basic Research Methods in Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to methods of psychological research, with special attention to hypothesis formation and testing, threats to validity, and data presentation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andPSYCH 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Research Methods in Sociology
courses.description: Experiential-based course covering the four main social research methods: available data, survey research, experiments, and field research.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits in Sociology

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (30 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: In consultation with your adviser, select 30 credits from social science courses in the following areas: ANTH, CAS, ECON, PLSC, PSYCH, or SOC. At least 15 of these credits should be at the 400 level, with 9 credits from one discipline and 6 credits from a second discipline.

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
Your courses will examine theoretical concepts and contemporary issues such as ethnic conflict, terrorism, global violence, and economic and political globalization. Studies in international and comparative politics — as well as in economics, geography, and history — round out this comprehensive degree.
You will also specialize with a unique concentration tailored to your interests in global politics.
curriculumDescription:
Create Your Own Learning Path
The B.A. in International Politics offers three areas of study for you to choose from:
International Political Economy
Provides for focused study at the intersection of politics and economics, with courses that allow students to engage with topics such as global trade, foreign investment, and international business
National Security Studies
Focuses on a study of global security, threats, and risks, with attention paid to addressing threats from state and non-state actors in the international system
International Relations
Offers a multidisciplinary foundation in the study of international affairs and is suitable for students who are interested in international politics but are not focused exclusively on economics or security studies
The Bachelor of Arts in International Politics degree requires students to complete a minimum of 123 credits.
A grade of "C" or better is required for all courses in the major.

Program Options (12 credits)
Choose one of the following program options. Courses for each program option will be determined in conjunction with your academic adviser.

Among the above degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses
The above course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: Contemporary Political Ideologies
courses.description: Critical analysis of contemporary political ideologies such as liberalism, conservatism, socialism, anarchism, fascism, feminism, and environmentalism.

courses.title: Comparing Politics Around the Globe
courses.description: This course examines the variety of ways that people seek and wield power around the world. Through cross-national comparison and individual country analysis, the course considers different forms of democratic and authoritarian regimes, sources of stability and change in different regime types, and the relationship between cultural, economic, and social factors and political processes.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Europe
courses.description: This course introduces students to the politics and governing institutions of European countries through a historical and comparative perspective.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102,ECON 104,orIB 303

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100orPLSC 14or permission of program

courses.title: American Foreign Policy
courses.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: Strategy and Politics
courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 1,PLSC 3, orPLSC 14

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102,ECON 104,orIB 303

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: National Security Policies
courses.description: Impact of national security on U.S. government and foreign policy; roles and interaction of President, Congress, government agencies, interest groups.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 001orPLSC 014

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100orPLSC 14or permission of program

courses.title: American Foreign Policy
courses.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: Politics and Institutions of Latin-American Nations
courses.description: Social forces and processes, governmental institutions, foreign policies of major states of Latin America.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 3orPLSC 200N

courses.title: International Relations of the Middle East
courses.description: The international relations of the Middle East, stressing national security policies of regional and outside actors, and major contemporary conflicts.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14orHIST 181

courses.title: Seminar in National Security Policy
courses.description: This course will examine the inter-relationship of foreign, military and economic policy.

courses.title: History of Modern Europe Since 1789
courses.description: Political, social, and ideological developments; origin and impact of two World Wars; totalitarianism and democracy; changing role in the world.

courses.title: The World at War: 1939–1945
courses.description: In-depth study of the origins and conduct of World War II. Political and economic aspects as well as military.

courses.title: Latin American since 1820
courses.description: Examines the history of modern Latin America, including the geographic and political development of the region, the development of various economic models, and the widespread extraction of labor focusing on African slavery and Indigenous exploitation.

courses.title: Introduction to the Middle East
courses.description: Origins of Islamic civilization; expansion of Islam; the Ottoman Empire; the Middle East since 1918.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Apocalyptic Geographies: How can we prevent the end of the world?
courses.description: Explores various visions of the apocalypse and their relevance for addressing major contemporary social, ecological, and economic issues. These issues include global climate change, nuclear war, the growing refugee crisis, the breakdown of democratic governance, economic recession, and forms of everyday violence and social fracture.

courses.title: Food and the Future Environment
courses.description: Introduces students to the multiple connections of people and the environment through the dynamics of food and the places where it is produced, processed, and consumed.

courses.title: Maps and the Geospatial Revolution
courses.description: Explores the fundamentals of cartography, geographic information science, and associated technologies through mapping and spatial analysis to answer key human and environmental problems.

courses.title: Environment and Society in a Changing World
courses.description: Introduction to the relationships between humans and the natural environment, in addition to the theories and methods that geographers employ in addressing them.

courses.title: Recent American History
courses.description: Contemporary economic, social, and political aspects of the United States and its role as a world power since 1945.

courses.title: The Contemporary Middle East
courses.description: Focuses on the political, economic, and social changes in Turkey, Iran, Israel, and the Arab countries in the twentieth century; explores the Arab-Israeli conflict.
courses.additionalInfo: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

courses.title: History of Imperialism and Nationalism in Africa
courses.description: A selective overview of the history of imperialism and nationalism in Africa.

courses.title: Human Use of Environment
courses.description: The human use of resources and ecosystems and social causes and consequences of environmental degradation in different parts of the world; development of environmental policy and management strategies.

courses.title: Geography of Water Resources
courses.description: Designed for students to understand the natural processes of aquatic ecosystems, management of water resources, and threats to sustaining water quantity and quality, for all types of freshwater surface, groundwater, rivers, lakes, wetlands.

courses.title: Energy Policy
courses.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.

courses.title: Human Dimensions of Global Warming
courses.description: Human dimensions of global environmental change: human causes; human adaptations; and policy implications of global warming.

courses.title: International Economics
courses.description: Why nations trade, barriers to trade, balance of payments adjustment and exchange rate determination, eurocurrency markets, and trade-related institutions.

courses.title: International Business Operations
courses.description: A survey of the major aspects of international business environment and operations with an emphasis on the cultural dimension.

allSections.sectionDescription: Take all (9 credits)

courses.title: Sociology of Deviance
courses.description: Theory and research concerning behaviors and lifestyles viewed as significant departures from a group's normative expectations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 12

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.

courses.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 111

courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 333

courses.title: International Finance and Open Economy Macroeconomics
courses.description: Trade balance movements, exchange rate determination; monetary and fiscal policies in open economies; international policy coordination; the world monetary system.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 304orECON 333

courses.title: Growth and Development
courses.description: Problems of capital formation, institutional considerations, theories of economic growth.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 302orECON 304orECON 372

courses.description: Examines the history of modern Latin America, including the geographic and political development of the region, the development of various economic models, and the widespread extraction of labor focusing on African slavery and Indigenous exploitation.

courses.title: Introduction to the Middle East
courses.description: Origins of Islamic civilization; expansion of Islam; the Ottoman Empire; the Middle East since 1918.

courses.title: Recent American History
courses.description: Contemporary economic, social, and political aspects of the United States and its role as a world power since 1945.

courses.title: The Contemporary Middle East
courses.description: Focuses on the political, economic, and social changes in Turkey, Iran, Israel, and the Arab countries in the twentieth century; explores the Arab-Israeli conflict.
courses.additionalInfo: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

courses.title: History of Imperialism and Nationalism in Africa
courses.description: A selective overview of the history of imperialism and nationalism in Africa.

courses.title: Apocalyptic Geographies: How can we prevent the end of the world?
courses.description: Explores various visions of the apocalypse and their relevance for addressing major contemporary social, ecological, and economic issues. These issues include global climate change, nuclear war, the growing refugee crisis, the breakdown of democratic governance, economic recession, and forms of everyday violence and social fracture.

courses.title: Food and the Future Environment
courses.description: Introduces students to the multiple connections of people and the environment through the dynamics of food and the places where it is produced, processed, and consumed.

courses.title: Maps and the Geospatial Revolution
courses.description: Explores the fundamentals of cartography, geographic information science, and associated technologies through mapping and spatial analysis to answer key human and environmental problems.

courses.title: Environment and Society in a Changing World
courses.description: Introduction to the relationships between humans and the natural environment, in addition to the theories and methods that geographers employ in addressing them.

courses.title: Human Use of Environment
courses.description: The human use of resources and ecosystems and social causes and consequences of environmental degradation in different parts of the world; development of environmental policy and management strategies.

courses.title: Geography of Water Resources
courses.description: Designed for students to understand the natural processes of aquatic ecosystems, management of water resources, and threats to sustaining water quantity and quality, for all types of freshwater surface, groundwater, rivers, lakes, wetlands.

courses.title: Energy Policy
courses.description: Analysis, formulation, implementation, and impacts of energy-related policies, regulations, and initiatives.

courses.title: Human Dimensions of Global Warming
courses.description: Human dimensions of global environmental change: human causes; human adaptations; and policy implications of global warming.

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: Contemporary Political Ideologies
courses.description: Critical analysis of contemporary political ideologies such as liberalism, conservatism, socialism, anarchism, fascism, feminism, and environmentalism.

courses.title: Comparing Politics Around the Globe
courses.description: This course examines the variety of ways that people seek and wield power around the world. Through cross-national comparison and individual country analysis, the course considers different forms of democratic and authoritarian regimes, sources of stability and change in different regime types, and the relationship between cultural, economic, and social factors and political processes.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Europe
courses.description: This course introduces students to the politics and governing institutions of European countries through a historical and comparative perspective.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102,ECON 104,orIB 303

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100orPLSC 14or permission of program

courses.title: American Foreign Policy
courses.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: Strategy and Politics
courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 1,PLSC 3, orPLSC 14

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102,ECON 104,orIB 303

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: National Security Policies
courses.description: Impact of national security on U.S. government and foreign policy; roles and interaction of President, Congress, government agencies, interest groups.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 001orPLSC 014

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100orPLSC 14or permission of program

courses.title: American Foreign Policy
courses.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14

courses.title: Politics and Institutions of Latin-American Nations
courses.description: Social forces and processes, governmental institutions, foreign policies of major states of Latin America.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 3orPLSC 200N

courses.title: International Relations of the Middle East
courses.description: The international relations of the Middle East, stressing national security policies of regional and outside actors, and major contemporary conflicts.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 14orHIST 181

courses.title: Seminar in National Security Policy
courses.description: This course will examine the inter-relationship of foreign, military and economic policy.

courses.title: Sociology of Deviance
courses.description: Theory and research concerning behaviors and lifestyles viewed as significant departures from a group's normative expectations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 12

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.

courses.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 111

coursesTabContent.programIntro: This online bachelor’s degree program introduces you to the core competencies of labor and human resources and related ethical questions, as well as instruction in research methods, economics, diversity, and organizational behavior.
curriculumDescription:
The Bachelor of Arts in Labor and Human Resources requires that you complete a minimum of 123 credits.
The course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.
Students must receive a grade of C or better in all courses required for the major. These include prescribed courses, additional courses, and supporting courses.

400-Level LHR Courses (select 6 credits)
Select 6 credits from any 400-level LHR courses. A maximum of 3 credits from LHR 495 and 3 credits of LHR 496 may be used to satisfy this requirement.
Select at least 6 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser.

or take 6 credits from any 400-level:
AFAM
CAS
ECON
HIST
MGMT
PHIL
PSYCH
SPAN
SOC
WMNST

courses.title: Exploring Work and Employment
courses.description: Introductory analysis of the employment relationship and the interrelated interests of management, workers, unions, and the public.

courses.title: Employment Relationship: Law and Policy
courses.description: Examination of basic legal principles underlying the employment relationship, and their social, political, and economic bases.

courses.title: Labor and Employment Relations Fundamentals
courses.description: The course surveys the main elements of modern labor and employment relations systems in the U.S. and beyond.

courses.title: Human Resources Fundamentals
courses.description: This course will provide students with an opportunity to understand and apply important concepts concerning human resources in the workplace.

courses.title: Research Methods in Labor Studies and Employment Relations
courses.description: The objective of this course is to enhance students' abilities to use a range of methodologies to evaluate and conduct research in the field of employment relations and human resource management.

courses.title: Ethics in the Workplace
courses.description: Explores ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100or fifth-semester standing or 3 other credits of LHR

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Race, Gender, and Employment
courses.description: This course will ask how race and gender affect work in the contemporary United States.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HIST 21orHIST 156orLER 100

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite HIST 21orHIST 156orLER 100

courses.title: Understanding Employee Behavior
courses.description: The course will be offered at an introductory level. It is designed to encourage students to explore individual and group behavior at work.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100

courses.title: Introduction to Industrial-Organizational Psychology
courses.description: Personnel selection, training, accident prevention, morale, and organizational behavior.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (12 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription:
400-Level LHR Courses (select 6 credits)
Select 6 credits from any 400-level LHR courses. A maximum of 3 credits from LHR 495 and 3 credits of LHR 496 may be used to satisfy this requirement.
Select at least 6 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or a higher math course or a satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Living While Black: Themes in African American Thought and Experience
courses.description: Explore what it means to be Black in America by engaging with questions about identity and authenticity, freedom and unfreedom, radicalism and reform, gender and sexuality, and the role of music in African American life.
courses.additionalInfo: GS and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

courses.title: Social, Legal, and Ethical Environment of Business
courses.description: Explores the ethical, political, social, legal and regulatory, technological, and demographic diversity environment of business.
courses.additionalInfo: Note A student may not receive credit toward graduation for bothBLAW 243andBA 243.

courses.title: Management and Organization
courses.description: An overview of a body of knowledge that exists concerning the management of modern organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ECON 102 or ECON 104

courses.title: Legal Environment of Business
courses.description: Social control through law: courts, basic policies underlying individual and contractual rights in everyday society.  May not be used to satisfy Smeal College baccalaureate degree requirements.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication
courses.description: This class is designed as an opportunity to explore the complexities of interpersonal communication and to develop a repertoire of interpersonal communication skills.

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.description: Examines the function and structure of communication in both formal and informal situations.

courses.title: Survey of Management
courses.description: Introduction to organizational factors relevant to management processes, including leadership, motivation, job design, technology, organizational design and environments, systems, change.

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts
courses.description: Study of fundamental principles and processes available to the understanding of management.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)and (ECON 102orECON 104)and (MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination)

courses.title: Leadership and Motivation
courses.description: Applies organizational behavior theories, concepts, and skills to leading and motivating individuals and groups.

courses.title: Introduction to Leadership

courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
courses.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Theory- and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision-making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Race, Ethnicity, and Culture

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
Courses in this online bachelor’s degree program focus on the critical content areas outlined in SHRM’s
HR Curriculum Guidebook
. This industry alignment and HR management focus ensures you can gain the core competencies to tackle today’s most pressing workplace challenges. Students preparing for SHRM-CP®, SHRM-SCP®, and aPHR® professional certifications should find the courses helpful.
curriculumDescription:
You can also customize your online HR degree by selecting an option that is relevant to your unique goals:
The
Human Resources (HR) option
focuses on the various functions that human resource management plays in helping organizations achieve the strategic objectives they choose to pursue.
The
Labor and Employment Relations (LER) option
provides the same opportunity for those choosing to focus on the labor movement as a career interest.

The B.S. in Labor and Human Resources program requires you to complete a minimum of 123 credits. Students must receive a grade of C or better in all courses required for the major. These include prescribed courses, additional courses, and supporting courses.

LHR courses that are used in the Additional Courses category may not be double-counted to satisfy other requirements. Some courses in this category have prerequisites that are not included in the major.

Elective courses should be chosen in consultation with an adviser. Among the degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses

Some courses in this category have prerequisites that are not included in the major.
Select 9 credits from any 400-level LHR courses (a maximum of 3 credits from LHR 495 or LHR 496 may be used to satisfy this requirement) and select 9–10 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser.

You may also select your 9–10 credits from any 400-level courses in:
AFAM
CAS
ECON
HIST
MGMT
PHIL
PSYCH
SPAN
SOC
WMNST

Some courses in this category have prerequisites that are not included in the major.
Select 6 credits from any 400-level LHR courses (a maximum of 3 credits from LHR 495 or LHR 496 may be used to satisfy this requirement) and select 12–13 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser.

You may also select your 12–13 credits from any 400-level courses in:
AFAM
CAS
ECON
HIST
LTNST
MGMT
PHIL
PSYCH
SPAN
SOC
WMNST

6 credits

9 credits

GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits

courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

courses.title: Introduction to Statistics for Business
courses.description: Introduces basic statistical concepts and models within the framework of business problems and applications. Discusses the usefulness of business statistics to decision-making, how to perform basic statistical and analytical procedures, and how to interpret, critically evaluate, and analyze data.

courses.title: Race, Gender, and Employment
courses.description: To accomplish the goals of the course, students will participate in a variety of in-class and out-of-class exercises designed to expose them to issues of inequality generally, and more specifically, to inequalities relating to employment. Activities are designed to connect real world experiences to class readings and discussion.

courses.title: Staffing and Training Strategies in Organizations
courses.description: This course focuses on the theory and practice of human resource staffing and training in organizations.

courses.title: Understanding Business Processes for LHR Professionals
courses.description: This course examines human resource management (HRM) and employment relations (ER) from a strategic perspective embedded in a complex and evolving organizational system.

courses.title: Total Rewards
courses.description: This course requires students to learn the link between company's strategy and compensation, and understand core policies necessary to develop effective compensation systems.

allSections.sectionTitle: Labor and Employment Relations Option Prescribed Courses (6 credits)

courses.title: Comparative Employment Relations Systems
courses.description: Analysis of structure and elements of employment relations systems in developed and developing areas.

courses.title: The Law of Labor-Management Relations
courses.description: Development of Anglo-American law regulating collective bargaining, with emphasis on American labor-management relations under Wagner, Taft-Hartley, and other acts.

allSections.sectionTitle: Labor and Employment Relations Option Additional Courses (select 6 credits)

courses.title: Total Rewards
courses.description: This course requires students to learn the link between company's strategy and compensation, and understand core policies necessary to develop effective compensation systems.

courses.title: Advanced Collective Bargaining and Contract Administration
courses.description: This course examines, at an advanced level, the theory, practice, and impact of the major phases of union organizing, collective bargaining, and contract administration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100

courses.title: Labor Relations in the Public Sector
courses.description: Upon completing this course, students should be able to identify the legal frameworks that govern collective bargaining between employers and unions in federal, state and local governments.

courses.title: Workplace Dispute Resolution
courses.description: This course examines dispute resolution procedures in unionized and nonunion workplaces.

courses.title: Workplace Safety and Health: Principles and Practices
courses.description: The role of employees, unions, employers, and government in dealing with work-related safety and health issues.

courses.title: Labor Union Structure, Administration, and Governance
courses.description: Comprehensive analysis of American Labor Unions/Labor Organizations: how structured, administered, and governed as they pursue economic, social, political objectives.

courses.title: American Labor Unions
courses.description: Students will examine, debate and gain a fundamental understanding of the current state of the American labor movement.

courses.title: Work-Life Practices and Policies
courses.description: Explore the causes and consequences of conflicts between work, family, and other life commitments, and how these may be resolved.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Understanding Employee Behavior
courses.description: The course will be offered at an introductory level. It is designed to encourage students to explore individual and group behavior at work.

courses.title: Introduction to Industrial-Organizational Psychology
courses.description: Personnel selection, training, accident prevention, morale, and organizational behavior.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

courses.title: Introduction to Statistics for Business
courses.description: Introduces basic statistical concepts and models within the framework of business problems and applications. Discusses the usefulness of business statistics to decision-making, how to perform basic statistical and analytical procedures, and how to interpret, critically evaluate, and analyze data.

courses.title: Race, Gender, and Employment
courses.description: To accomplish the goals of the course, students will participate in a variety of in-class and out-of-class exercises designed to expose them to issues of inequality generally, and more specifically, to inequalities relating to employment. Activities are designed to connect real world experiences to class readings and discussion.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courseSections.sectionDescription:
Elective courses should be chosen in consultation with an adviser. Among the degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses

courseSections.sectionTitle: Human Resources Option Prescribed Courses (12 credits)

courses.title: International Human Resource Studies
courses.description: Course exploring human resource management from an international perspective.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100

courses.title: Staffing and Training Strategies in Organizations
courses.description: This course focuses on the theory and practice of human resource staffing and training in organizations.

courses.title: Understanding Business Processes for LHR Professionals
courses.description: This course examines human resource management (HRM) and employment relations (ER) from a strategic perspective embedded in a complex and evolving organizational system.

courses.title: Total Rewards
courses.description: This course requires students to learn the link between company's strategy and compensation, and understand core policies necessary to develop effective compensation systems.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100

courseSections.sectionTitle: Human Resources Option Supporting and Related Courses (18–19 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription:
Some courses in this category have prerequisites that are not included in the major.
Select 9 credits from any 400-level LHR courses (a maximum of 3 credits from LHR 495 or LHR 496 may be used to satisfy this requirement) and select 9–10 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or a higher math course or a satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Living While Black: Themes in African American Thought and Experience
courses.description: Explore what it means to be Black in America by engaging with questions about identity and authenticity, freedom and unfreedom, radicalism and reform, gender and sexuality, and the role of music in African American life.
courses.additionalInfo: GS and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

courses.title: Social, Legal, and Ethical Environment of Business
courses.description: Explores the ethical, political, social, legal and regulatory, technological, and demographic diversity environment of business.
courses.additionalInfo: Note A student may not receive credit toward graduation for bothBLAW 243andBA 243.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication
courses.description: This class is designed as an opportunity to explore the complexities of interpersonal communication and to develop a repertoire of interpersonal communication skills.

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.description: Examines the function and structure of communication in both formal and informal situations.

courses.title: Survey of Management
courses.description: Introduction to organizational factors relevant to management processes, including leadership, motivation, job design, technology, organizational design and environments, systems, change.

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts
courses.description: Study of fundamental principles and processes available to the understanding of management.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)and (ECON 102orECON 104)and (MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination)

courses.title: Leadership and Motivation
courses.description: Applies organizational behavior theories, concepts, and skills to leading and motivating individuals and groups.

courses.title: Introduction to Leadership
courses.description: This course introduces key leadership concepts and practices based on current theory and research. It is designed to help students to discover the knowledge and skills that are characteristic of effective leaders.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
courses.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Theory- and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision-making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Race, Ethnicity, and Culture
courses.description: Focuses on historical patterns and current status of racial, ethnic and cultural groups and issues locally, nationally, and internationally.
courses.additionalInfo: GS and US The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement and the United States Cultures (US) requirement.

courseSections.sectionTitle: Labor and Employment Relations Option Prescribed Courses (6 credits)

courses.title: Comparative Employment Relations Systems
courses.description: Analysis of structure and elements of employment relations systems in developed and developing areas.

courses.title: The Law of Labor-Management Relations
courses.description: Development of Anglo-American law regulating collective bargaining, with emphasis on American labor-management relations under Wagner, Taft-Hartley, and other acts.

courseSections.sectionTitle: Labor and Employment Relations Option Additional Courses (select 6 credits)

courses.title: Total Rewards
courses.description: This course requires students to learn the link between company's strategy and compensation, and understand core policies necessary to develop effective compensation systems.

courses.title: Advanced Collective Bargaining and Contract Administration
courses.description: This course examines, at an advanced level, the theory, practice, and impact of the major phases of union organizing, collective bargaining, and contract administration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100

courses.title: Labor Relations in the Public Sector
courses.description: Upon completing this course, students should be able to identify the legal frameworks that govern collective bargaining between employers and unions in federal, state and local governments.

courses.title: Workplace Dispute Resolution
courses.description: This course examines dispute resolution procedures in unionized and nonunion workplaces.

courses.title: Workplace Safety and Health: Principles and Practices
courses.description: The role of employees, unions, employers, and government in dealing with work-related safety and health issues.

courses.title: Labor Union Structure, Administration, and Governance
courses.description: Comprehensive analysis of American Labor Unions/Labor Organizations: how structured, administered, and governed as they pursue economic, social, political objectives.

courses.title: American Labor Unions
courses.description: Students will examine, debate and gain a fundamental understanding of the current state of the American labor movement.

courses.title: Work-Life Practices and Policies
courses.description: Explore the causes and consequences of conflicts between work, family, and other life commitments, and how these may be resolved.

courseSections.sectionTitle: Labor and Employment Relations Option Supporting and Related Courses (18–19 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription:
Some courses in this category have prerequisites that are not included in the major.
Select 6 credits from any 400-level LHR courses (a maximum of 3 credits from LHR 495 or LHR 496 may be used to satisfy this requirement) and select 12–13 credits from the following list in consultation with an adviser.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or a higher math course or a satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Social, Legal, and Ethical Environment of Business
courses.description: Explores the ethical, political, social, legal and regulatory, technological, and demographic diversity environment of business.
courses.additionalInfo: Note A student may not receive credit toward graduation for bothBLAW 243andBA 243.

courses.title: Legal Environment of Business
courses.description: Social control through law: courts, basic policies underlying individual and contractual rights in everyday society.  May not be used to satisfy Smeal College baccalaureate degree requirements.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication
courses.description: This class is designed as an opportunity to explore the complexities of interpersonal communication and to develop a repertoire of interpersonal communication skills.

courses.title: Organizational Communication

courseSections.sectionDescription:
Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: As a law and society student, your 15 credits of core online course work will include legal brief–writing and the philosophy of law and legal ethics. Throughout your studies, you can master the foundational concepts needed to critically analyze arguments and detect careless language use and fallacies.
curriculumDescription:
The prescribed and supporting courses in this program focus on contemporary issues in U.S. law and ethics. Many different course options are available to fulfill the remainder of the 120 credits required for the program, allowing you to customize the degree to meet your specific goals.
The course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.
A student enrolled in this major must receive a grade of C or better in all courses required for the major.

The prescribed courses focus on contemporary issues in U.S. law and ethics. Students will take these 15 credits and three additional credits selected in consultation with their academic adviser.
A grade of C or better is required for all courses in the major.

Select 6 credits from the following course listing. Students planning to attend law school are encouraged to complete both PHIL 10 and PHIL 12. Additional courses from a department approved list may also be taken to meet these requirements.
A grade of C or better is required for these courses.

Select 15 credits from the following, with at least 12 credits at the 400 level. Additional courses from a department approved list may also be taken to meet these requirements.
A grade of C or better is required for these courses.

Elective courses should be chosen in consultation with an adviser. Among the degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

allSections.sectionDescription:
The prescribed courses focus on contemporary issues in U.S. law and ethics. Students will take these 15 credits and three additional credits selected in consultation with their academic adviser.
A grade of C or better is required for all courses in the major.

courses.title: American Civilization to 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from its colonial beginnings through the Civil War and Reconstruction.

courses.title: American Civilization Since 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from the emergence of urban-industrial society in the late nineteenth century to the present.

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: Experiential Learning Portfolio
courses.description: Students will learn how to assemble a portfolio that reflects their progress, knowledge, and insight into college-level study.

courses.title: Rights in America
courses.description: This course explores the historical and contemporary struggles of particular groups within American society to expand their rights.

courses.title: The American Legal Process
courses.description: Analysis of the roles, procedures, and policies characterizing the American legal system.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 1

allSections.sectionDescription:
Select 6 credits from the following course listing. Students planning to attend law school are encouraged to complete both PHIL 10 and PHIL 12. Additional courses from a department approved list may also be taken to meet these requirements.
A grade of C or better is required for these courses.

courses.title: Argumentation
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth examination of argumentation in both public and private contexts.

courses.title: Rhetoric and Law
courses.description: A survey of the literature on the role of rhetoric in law, including trial advocacy, appellate argument, and judicial reasoning.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: An understanding of both qualitative research methods and the theoretical frameworks that inform qualitative inquiry. Additionally, this course focuses on tools for data collection such as individual and focus-group interviewing and observing and recording interaction. This course provides practical experience for students in collecting and analyzing qualitative data with and without the use of technology and examines particular difficulties in the interpretation and reporting of qualitative findings. Qualitative Research Methods is course that bridges disciplinary boundaries and is useful to any student who will be investigating human interaction.

courses.title: Critical Thinking
courses.description: Discussion of the validity, soundness, and fallacies of everyday language use and reasoning; informal logic; and manipulative arguments and propaganda.

courses.title: Symbolic Logic
courses.description: In this course, students will first learn basic vocabulary for argument analysis, standards for evaluating arguments that are expressed in English, and basic methods for testing these arguments along with the shortcomings of said methods.

courses.title: Scientific Study of Politics
courses.description: This course introduces students to both the scientific study of politics and the way that study advances our understanding of political actors, events, processes, and institutions.

courses.title: Quantitative Political Analysis
courses.description: Data analysis and statistical applications in political research, including data processing, inferential statistics, contingency analysis, correlation and regression, and multivariate analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite any 3 credits in political science

courses.title: Research Methods in Sociology
courses.description: Experiential-based course covering the four main social research methods: available data, survey research, experiments, and field research.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits in Sociology

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (15 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription:
Select 15 credits from the following, with at least 12 credits at the 400 level. Additional courses from a department approved list may also be taken to meet these requirements.
A grade of C or better is required for these courses.

courses.title: Business and Professional Communication
courses.description: Review and practice of various communication forms used in modern organizations.

courses.title: Conflict Resolution and Negotiation
courses.description: Theories and strategies important for conceptualizing, developing, and managing conflict negotiation, mediation, and third-party intervention.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CAS 100

courses.title: Communication Ethics
courses.description: Ethical issues in public and private communication; role of communication in expressing and realizing individual and social values.

courses.title: Studies in Public Address
courses.description: History and criticism of public discourse; intensive analysis of selected public addresses and social movements.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 6 credits of CAS

courses.title: Criminology
courses.description: Explanations and measurement of crime; criminal law; characteristics of criminals and victims; violent, property, white-collar, organized, and sexual crimes.

courses.title: Introduction to Criminal Justice
courses.description: Overview of the criminal justice system, including legal foundations, processing and correction of offenders, extent and types of crime, victims.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Law
courses.description: Introduction to law in society with a focus on criminal law, judicial code, laws of sentencing and corrections, ciminal procedure.

courses.title: Law and Society
courses.description: The social origins of law and legal systems; occupational careers; and decision-making of legal officials.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100orCRIMJ 113

courses.title: Law and Society
courses.description: Law and Society studies the social origins of law and legal systems, occupational careers, and decision-making of legal officials.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIM 100orCRIM 113

courses.title: Courts and the Prosecution Process
courses.description: Purpose and function of criminal courts in society, organization, jurisdiction and staffing; prosecution, adjudication, and sentencing of offenders.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CRIMJ 100
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Criminal Law and Procedure
courses.description: Common law and statutory crimes; constitutional rights of accused persons, liability of criminal justice professionals.

courses.title: Fundraising Leadership: Building a Strong Base
courses.description: Focused on the fundamentals of fundraising and leadership, including communications, management of events and people, and stewardship.

courses.title: Careers in Fundraising and Development
courses.description: Guides students through an introduction to the fundraising/advancement profession, including a review of the history and emergence of the profession. Touches on key issues such as professional ethics and the legal environment of the field.

courses.title: Independent Studies
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 60 undergraduate credits and permission of program

courses.title: Employment Relationship: Law and Policy
courses.description: Examination of basic legal principles underlying the employment relationship, and their social, political, and economic bases.

courses.title: The Law of Labor-Management Relations
courses.description: Development of Anglo-American law regulating collective bargaining, with emphasis on American labor-management relations under Wagner, Taft-Hartley, and other acts.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits in labor and industrial relations or political science

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Completed 60 credits & permission from the program

courses.title: Introduction to Ethics
courses.description: Ethical theory about virtue, duty, autonomy, and life quality applied to moral problems, including character, violence, oppression, abortion, and suicide.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030or permission of program

courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Law and Legal Ethics
courses.description: Historical and contemporary philosophies of law; concepts of responsibility, property, rights, and justice; and ethical issues in legal practice.

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

courses.title: Rights in America
courses.description: This course explores the historical and contemporary struggles of particular groups within American society to expand their rights.

courses.title: American Constitutional Law
courses.description: The origins of judicial review, landmark decisions of the Supreme Court, and their impact on the American form of government.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 1

courses.title: American Judicial Behavior
courses.description: Analyzes behavior of judges and other participants in the legal process; examines how and why courts function as policymaking bodies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 1
