courses.title: Business and Professional Communication
courses.description: Review and practice of various communication forms used in modern organizations.

courses.title: Conflict Resolution and Negotiation
courses.description: Theories and strategies important for conceptualizing, developing, and managing conflict negotiation, mediation, and third-party intervention.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CAS 100

courses.title: Communication Ethics
courses.description: Ethical issues in public and private communication; role of communication in expressing and realizing individual and social values.

courses.title: Studies in Public Address
courses.description: History and criticism of public discourse; intensive analysis of selected public addresses and social movements.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 6 credits of CAS

courses.title: Criminology
courses.description: Explanations and measurement of crime; criminal law; characteristics of criminals and victims; violent, property, white-collar, organized, and sexual crimes.

courses.title: Introduction to Criminal Justice
courses.description: Overview of the criminal justice system, including legal foundations, processing and correction of offenders, extent and types of crime, victims.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Law
courses.description: Introduction to law in society with a focus on criminal law, judicial code, laws of sentencing and corrections, ciminal procedure.

courses.title: Law and Society
courses.description: The social origins of law and legal systems; occupational careers; and decision-making of legal officials.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIMJ 100orCRIMJ 113

courses.title: Law and Society
courses.description: Law and Society studies the social origins of law and legal systems, occupational careers, and decision-making of legal officials.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CRIM 100orCRIM 113

courses.title: Courts and the Prosecution Process
courses.description: Purpose and function of criminal courts in society, organization, jurisdiction and staffing; prosecution, adjudication, and sentencing of offenders.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CRIMJ 100
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Criminal Law and Procedure
courses.description: Common law and statutory crimes; constitutional rights of accused persons, liability of criminal justice professionals.

courses.title: Fundraising Leadership: Building a Strong Base
courses.description: Focused on the fundamentals of fundraising and leadership, including communications, management of events and people, and stewardship.

courses.title: Careers in Fundraising and Development
courses.description: Guides students through an introduction to the fundraising/advancement profession, including a review of the history and emergence of the profession. Touches on key issues such as professional ethics and the legal environment of the field.

courses.title: Independent Studies
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 60 undergraduate credits and permission of program

courses.title: Employment Relationship: Law and Policy
courses.description: Examination of basic legal principles underlying the employment relationship, and their social, political, and economic bases.

courses.title: The Law of Labor-Management Relations
courses.description: Development of Anglo-American law regulating collective bargaining, with emphasis on American labor-management relations under Wagner, Taft-Hartley, and other acts.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits in labor and industrial relations or political science

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Completed 60 credits & permission from the program

courses.title: Introduction to Ethics
courses.description: Ethical theory about virtue, duty, autonomy, and life quality applied to moral problems, including character, violence, oppression, abortion, and suicide.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030or permission of program

courses.title: Introduction to Philosophy of Law and Legal Ethics
courses.description: Historical and contemporary philosophies of law; concepts of responsibility, property, rights, and justice; and ethical issues in legal practice.

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

courses.title: Rights in America
courses.description: This course explores the historical and contemporary struggles of particular groups within American society to expand their rights.

courses.title: American Constitutional Law
courses.description: The origins of judicial review, landmark decisions of the Supreme Court, and their impact on the American form of government.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 1

courses.title: American Judicial Behavior
courses.description: Analyzes behavior of judges and other participants in the legal process; examines how and why courts function as policymaking bodies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PLSC 1

courseSections.sectionDescription:
Elective courses should be chosen in consultation with an adviser. Among the degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

coursesTabContent.programIntro: Penn State’s online marketing degree program features in-depth course work to help you understand business operations and how marketing professionals and institutions work together for business success.
curriculumDescription:
Your marketing degree online course work will cover retailing, advertising and sales promotion, marketing management, research, e-commerce, and more. To appreciate how businesses operate, you will also complete business-focused courses in such disciplines as business strategy, supply chain, and finance. A final capstone project allows you to leverage your skills to research and develop a fully integrated strategic marketing plan.
Courses cover a wide range of marketing topics, including:
business-to-business marketing
consumer behavior
digital advertising
social media management
sales management
global marketing
marketing techniques for electronic commerce
advertising and sales promotion
services marketing
marketing research

Select 12 credits of 200- to 400-level business courses from:
ACCTG
BA
ECON
FIN
MGMT
MIS
MKTG
SCM
in consultation with an academic adviser and in support of the student's interests.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

Among the degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses
This course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.

This online Bachelor of Science in Marketing integrates with the residential MBA program at Penn State Harrisburg. For information regarding this accelerated MBA opportunity, contact
maa31@psu.edu
.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21or 1.5 units of high school algebra

courses.title: International Business and Society
courses.description: Business organizations and the sociocultural environment; current issues; corporate responsibility; international and multinational business environments.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202DandMGMT 301

courses.title: Business Strategy
courses.description: Interpretation of business concepts in the analysis of problems related to the successful management of a company, institution, or organization.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite FIN 301andMGMT 301andMKTG 301W

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ENGL 15orENGL 30
Note A student may take only one course for credit from ENGL 202A, 202B, 202C, and 202D.

courses.title: Corporation Finance
courses.description: Nature of finance function; risk and return concepts; working capital; dividend policies; mergers; security markets; acquisition and management of corporate capital; analysis of operations; forecasting capital requirements; raising capital; and planning profits. Available to baccalaureate students only.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)andACCTG 211and (ECON 102orECON 104) and (SCM 200orSTAT 200)

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts
courses.description: Study of fundamental principles and processes available to the understanding of management.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)and (ECON 102orECON 104)and (MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination)

courses.title: Introduction to Management Information Systems
courses.description: Provides an overview of the role of information systems in business process design; the current technologies used for obtaining, storing, securing, and communicating information in support of operations and decision-making within a business organization; as well as the concepts and principles for developing and using popular spreadsheet and database tools.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Problem-Solving with Spreadsheet Analysis and Information Systems Management
courses.description: This course explores the application of spreadsheet engineering concepts and principles of data management, business modeling, and reporting to business problems.

courses.title: Information Systems Management and Applications
courses.description: Specification, design and implementation of information systems directed at aiding decision-making in organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MIS 204

courses.title: Principles of Marketing
courses.description: Covers terminology and important concepts related to marketing in the business environment. Domestic and international environments that impact marketing are included, with particular emphasis on the marketing environment, segmentation, positioning, and targeting.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030;ECON 102orECON 104;MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Consumer Behavior
courses.description: Application of behavioral science concepts to the understanding of buyer behavior as a basis for marketing management decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Marketing Research
courses.description: Research approaches, methods, and applications studied as a formal approach to problem-solving for marketing decisions.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite BA 303orMKTG 301W;SCM 200orSTAT 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Marketing Strategy
courses.description: Market-oriented problems of the firm; identification and selection of market opportunities; formulation of competitive strategies; marketing policies and programs.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MKTG 330andMKTG 342
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Supply Chain Management
courses.description: Supply chain management concepts, principles, and methodologies.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ACCTG 211orECON 102orSCM 200orSTAT 200; limited to students in baccalaureate status.

courses.title: Social, Legal, and Ethical Environment of Business
courses.description: Explores the ethical, political, social, legal and regulatory, technological, and demographic diversity environment of business.
courses.additionalInfo: Note A student may not receive credit toward graduation for bothBLAW 243andBA 243.

courses.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to foundational concepts that are used in the data analytics industry to understand and frame projects
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 22or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
Note Students may take only one course for credit from MATH 110, 140, 140A, and 140B.
GQ The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 22or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
Note Students may take only one course for credit from MATH 110, 140, 140A, and 140B.
GQ The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (MATH 22andMATH 26) orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
Note Students may only take one course for credit from MATH 110, 140, 140A, 140B, and 140H.
GQ The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 021or higher.
GQ This course can be used to satisfy the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.title: Industrial Organization
courses.description: Focuses on the study of markets with imperfect competition.

courses.title: Retailing
courses.description: Management of marketing institutions in distribution channels from producers to consumers. Emphasis on retail institutions: location, personnel, merchandising, control, promotion.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite BA 303orMKTG 301W
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Advertising and Sales Promotion Management
courses.description: Perspectives and models of the key decisions involved in managing advertising and sales promotion campaigns.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MKTG 330orMKTG 342
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Global Marketing
courses.description: Role of international marketing in the global environment; political, economic, geographic, historical, cultural conditions; developing and implementing international marketing strategies.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite BA 303orMKTG 301W
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Sales Management
courses.description: Application of modern management principles to field sales force planning, organization, and administration; selection, training, and compensation plans.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MKTG 301WandMGMT 301
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Services Marketing Management
courses.description: Conceptual understanding of services and the analytical tools that are used in solving strategic services marketing problems.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MKTG 301W
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: Customize your education by choosing from a wide variety of courses offered by the Penn State College of the Liberal Arts to create a truly unique degree program. You will investigate a theme from the viewpoint of at least three different subject areas.
curriculumDescription:
Multidisciplinary Studies is a theme-oriented and student-designed major leading to a bachelor of arts degree. Learners have the flexibility to design a theme-based program of study that reflects their career goals with the guidance of their academic adviser.
To understand the creative integration of topics, here are a few sample themes from previous students:
Technology and Public Policy
Information Technology and Law Enforcement
Politics, History, and the Music Entertainment Business
Communications in Health, Wellness, and Environment
Business and Leadership for Successful Organizations
Writing and Illustrating Children's Literature

Courses must be selected in consultation with an adviser. A student enrolled in this major must receive a grade of "C" or better in the 36 required course credits for the major. Four different course themes are available to fulfill program requirements:
communication skills
critical analysis
research methods/projects
theory/application

Courses require a grade of "C" or better. Select 24 credits from University-wide offerings to include:
12 credits at the 400 level representing at least three different subject areas
3-credit, 400-level capstone course
A minimum 9 credits from the humanities and social sciences

Courses require a grade of "C" or better.
Select 3 credits in research methods/projects from courses that involve research methodology or that focus on a research project
Select 3 credits in communication skills from courses that focus on expression, including those in verbal, symbolic, and written skills
Select 3 credits in theory/application from courses that focus on theory, principle, central concepts, or fundamental issues
Select 3 credits in critical analysis from courses that focus on evaluation, synthesis, and analysis

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

Among the degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses
The course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: The RN to BSN degree's core courses focus on contemporary issues in the field of nursing. Subjects of study include anatomy, chemistry, data management, ethics, health assessment, human development and family studies, human resources management, microbiology, nursing research, nutrition, and sociology.
curriculumDescription:
Our nursing degree courses are online, and you can fulfill your clinical requirements near your home. Some nursing courses are available in an
accelerated seven-week format
.
The RN to BSN program is 120 credits. To earn this Bachelor of Science in Nursing, you must successfully complete:
42 prescribed core course credits
45 General Education credits
33 additional core credits (earned by portfolio verification for licensed RNs)
The degree's prescribed core courses focus on contemporary issues in the field of nursing. Subjects of study include anatomy, chemistry, data management, ethics, health assessment, human development and family studies, human resources management, microbiology, nursing research, nutrition, and sociology.
Program Requirements
: 120 credits
You may transfer credits into this program from another accredited institution. However, to earn this Bachelor of Science in Nursing, you must earn 36 of the last 60 credits from Penn State.
General Education
: 45 credits
(20–22 of these 45 credits are included in the
requirements for the major
.)
(See General Education in the curriculum.)
Requirements for the Major
: 92–93 credits
(This includes 20–22 credits of General Education courses.)
Electives
: 2–5 credits
The following courses comprise credits earned by credit by portfolio assessment for RNs.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.

Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits

Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits

GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the

.

courses.title: Principles of Nursing Research and Evidence-Based Practice
courses.description: Introduction to principles and methods of nursing research and application of, research evidence to practice.

courses.title: Advanced Health Assessment for the Registered Nurse
courses.description: Designed to extend the RN student's knowledge and skills in health assessment and physical examination across the lifespan.

courses.title: Introduction to Nursing Informatics
courses.description: An introduction to nursing informatics focusing on technology applications to the nursing profession.

courses.title: Transition and the Professional Nursing Role
courses.description: Transition to baccalaureate education and professional nursing practice, emphasizing leadership, management, and issues influencing nursing education and practice.

courses.title: Family and Community Health Concepts
courses.description: Study of the concepts of family and community based nursing care emphasizing multicultural influences on health practices.

courses.title: Health Concepts for Adults with Complex Health Care Needs
courses.description: In-depth study and application of the theoretical principles and roles of adult clients and families with complex healthcare needs.

courses.title: Integrated Concepts in Nursing Practice
courses.description: A project-based capstone clinical course for the RN student with a focus on the application of nursing concepts and the RN's development of future career goals. The course is designed to provide opportunity for students to synthesize and apply the art and science of nursing to health promotion and disease prevention in culturally diverse populations in varied clinical settings of the global community.

allSections.sectionDescription: The following courses comprise credits earned by credit by portfolio assessment for RNs.

courses.title: Pathophysiology
courses.description: Designed to explore the illness component of health with emphasis on the pathophysiological and psychosocial aspects.

courses.title: Introduction to the Fundamentals of Nursing
courses.description: Introduction to the nursing process, clinical competencies and psychosocial skills.

courses.title: Professional Role Dev I: Intro to Professional Issues in Nursing Practice and Nursing Informatics
courses.description: Introduces the students to the profession of nursing, the science of nursing, and the use of information technology in health care.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite BIOL 161andBIOL 163

courses.title: Nursing Care of Client through the Adult Life Span Requiring Medical Intervention
courses.description: Therapeutic nursing care of the adult client in a variety of primarily medical-surgical settings.

courses.title: Introduction to Pharmacological Concepts
courses.description: Introduction to pharmacological concepts and identifies the pharmacodynamics of major classifications of drugs.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite NURS 225andNURS 230or approval of the program.
Recommended Corequisites NURS 301andNURS 310

courses.title: Nursing Care of Children and Adolescents
courses.description: Focuses on common health problems and nursing intervention for children and adolescents.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite NURS 225andNURS 230andNURS 305

courses.title: Therapeutic Nursing Care of the Older Adult Client
courses.description: Nursing concerns and intervention in promoting the health of the older adult.

courses.title: Nursing Care of the Childbearing Family and Gynecological Client
courses.description: Therapeutic nursing care of the childbearing family and gynecological client.

courses.title: Nursing Care of the Adult Client with Complex Health Problems: Part B
courses.description: In-depth study of care of patients with acute and complex health problems, utilizing evidence-based practice.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite NURS 305andNURS 350

courses.title: Mental Health Nursing
courses.description: Emphasizes clinical application of mental health theory in nursing care of patients with acute and chronic mental health problems.

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Courses (select 6 credits)

courses.title: Violence and the Impact on Society
courses.description: Interdisciplinary discussion of violence and its perpetrators, victims, and impact on society as well as possible solutions for violence reduction.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Health and Environmental Sustainability
courses.description: This course covers the importance of environmental health on individual and community health, the effects of environmental hazards on diverse populations and the impact of climate change on disease.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Forensic Nursing
courses.description: Provides an introduction to the forensic health sciences, forensic nursing, and the nursing role in the scientific investigation of violence.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite NURS 225,NURS 230,NURS 250
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Forensic Evidence Collection and Preservation
courses.description: Examines nurses' role of recognizing patterns of injury. Evidence collection procedures are examined from collection to courtroom presentation, includes autopsy.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite or concurrent NURS 245andNURS 409
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Seminar in Forensic Nursing
courses.description: A seminar to discuss the current topics, trends, and research related to forensic nursing, including evidence-based research, public policy issues, media-related events, regulatory considerations, professional responsibilities, and career planning.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite or concurrent NURS 410
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Organization and Administration for the Nurse Manager
courses.description: Introduction to organizational theory and principles of practice in the administration of nursing services and patient care.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Data Management for Nurse Managers
courses.description: Analysis of information systems to manage nursing service organizations. Includes financial management, the budgeting processes, and productivity measurement.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Nursing Management of Human Resources
courses.description: Human resource management and related factors in nursing service organizations.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Seminar for Nurse Managers
courses.description: Focuses on the application of management principles in the role of the nurse manager.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite NURS 430
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Trauma/Critical Care Nursing
courses.description: Focuses on the impact of and the nursing care of persons experiencing acute trauma and/or critical illness.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Ethical Challenges in Health Care Informatics
courses.description: A case-based collaboratory designed for the exploration and analysis of the ethical dilemmas facing health care informatics practitioners.
courses.additionalInfo: C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Advanced Concepts in Clinical Nursing Informatics
courses.description: An exploration of clinical informatics tools to support informatics practice.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite NURS 357
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Nursing Study in Specialized Setting
courses.description: Designed to provide students with in-depth study and practice in clinical specialty area of choice. Students work with a faculty member in the development of course objectives and goals and with a clinical preceptor to accomplish them.

courses.title: Independent Studies
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

courses.title: Mammalian Anatomy
courses.description: Anatomy of a mammal, with special reference to that of man.
courses.additionalInfo: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Physiology
courses.description: Normal structure and function of the animal body, with special emphasis on human body systems.

courses.title: Effective Speech
courses.description: Principles of communication, implemented through analysis and evaluation of messages, with some attention to formal speaking and group discussion.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Chemical Principles I
courses.description: Basic concepts and quantitative relations.
courses.additionalInfo: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Experimental Chemistry I
courses.description: Introduction to quantitative experimentation in chemistry.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite or Concurrent CHEM 110orCHEM 106

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Instruction and practice in writing expository prose that shows sensitivity to audience and purpose.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Writing in the Social Sciences
courses.description: Introduces students to the types of writing that social scientists typically do in the workplace, including research proposals, proper citation practices, literature reviews, and research reports.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Writing in the Humanities
courses.description: Instruction in writing persuasive arguments about significant issues in the humanities.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing
GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.

courses.title: Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies
courses.description: Introduction to psychosocial and family development at all stages of the individual and family life cycle.
courses.additionalInfo: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Elementary Microbiology
courses.description: A survey course in microbiology for non-majors, this course focuses on the roles of microbes in human health and disease, agriculture, biotechnology, and other areas of societal impact.
courses.additionalInfo: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Elementary Microbiology Laboratory
courses.description: Selected techniques used to observe, identify, and count bacteria; effects of chemical and physical agents on microorganisms. The combination of MICRB 106 GN and 107 GN must be taken to receive General Education credit in biology.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MICRB 106
GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Principles of Nutrition
courses.description: The nutrients: food sources and physiological functions as related to human growth and well-being throughout life; current nutrition issues.
courses.additionalInfo: GHW This course can be used to satisfy the Health and Wellness (GHW) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Sociology
courses.description: The nature and characteristics of human societies and social life.
courses.additionalInfo: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Social Problems
courses.description: Current social problems such as economic, racial, and gender inequalities; social deviance and crime; population, environmental, energy, and health problems.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: GQ This course can be used to satisfy the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.additionalInfo: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Physiology
courses.description: Normal structure and function of the animal body, with special emphasis on human body systems.

courses.title: Effective Speech
courses.description: Principles of communication, implemented through analysis and evaluation of messages, with some attention to formal speaking and group discussion.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Chemical Principles I
courses.description: Basic concepts and quantitative relations.
courses.additionalInfo: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Experimental Chemistry I
courses.description: Introduction to quantitative experimentation in chemistry.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite or Concurrent CHEM 110orCHEM 106

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Instruction and practice in writing expository prose that shows sensitivity to audience and purpose.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Writing in the Social Sciences
courses.description: Introduces students to the types of writing that social scientists typically do in the workplace, including research proposals, proper citation practices, literature reviews, and research reports.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Writing in the Humanities
courses.description: Instruction in writing persuasive arguments about significant issues in the humanities.
courses.additionalInfo: GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing
GWS This course can be used to satisfy the Writing/Speaking (GWS) requirement.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.

courses.title: Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies
courses.description: Introduction to psychosocial and family development at all stages of the individual and family life cycle.
courses.additionalInfo: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Elementary Microbiology
courses.description: A survey course in microbiology for non-majors, this course focuses on the roles of microbes in human health and disease, agriculture, biotechnology, and other areas of societal impact.
courses.additionalInfo: GN This course can be used to satisfy the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Elementary Microbiology Laboratory
courses.description: Selected techniques used to observe, identify, and count bacteria; effects of chemical and physical agents on microorganisms. The combination of MICRB 106 GN and 107 GN must be taken to receive General Education credit in biology.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MICRB 106
GN The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Natural Sciences (GN) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Principles of Nutrition
courses.description: The nutrients: food sources and physiological functions as related to human growth and well-being throughout life; current nutrition issues.
courses.additionalInfo: GHW This course can be used to satisfy the Health and Wellness (GHW) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Introductory Sociology
courses.description: The nature and characteristics of human societies and social life.
courses.additionalInfo: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Social Problems
courses.description: Current social problems such as economic, racial, and gender inequalities; social deviance and crime; population, environmental, energy, and health problems.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: GQ This course can be used to satisfy the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courseSections.sectionDescription:
Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: A Penn State organizational and professional communication degree is constructed to encourage you to tailor your communication studies to meet the needs of the modern-day organization.
curriculumDescription:
The Bachelor of Arts in Organizational and Professional Communication requires you to complete a minimum of 120 credits.
Explore course work in subject areas such as:
Research Methods
— Focus on data collection tools for focus-group interviewing, observing, and recording to inform qualitative inquiry based on theoretical frameworks.
Communication Theory
— Apply communication theory to examine interpersonal, group, organizational, mediated, and cross-cultural interactions.
Communication Ethics
— Learn the role of communication in ethical issues and expressing and realizing individual and social values.
If you are a transfer student, the number of credits you must take will vary according to the courses that transfer into the program. Once you are admitted to the program, your assigned academic adviser can help you select the remaining required courses.
A grade of C or better is required for all courses in the major.
Select 15 credits from the following courses; at least 9 credits must be at the 400-level.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Communication Research Methods
courses.description: Overview of the skills necessary to evaluate commonly reported communication research.

courses.title: Rhetorical Theory
courses.description: History and theory of public advocacy and civic discourse.

courses.title: Introduction to Communication Theory
courses.description: This course is intended as a foundational course in communication theory for Communication Arts and Sciences majors and others interested in social science theory in general. It is designed to show how communication theory can be applied to understand and improve communication in your professional (and personal) life. The theories examined will span the range of communication contexts, including interpersonal, group, organizational, mediated, and cross-cultural interactions.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: An understanding of both qualitative research methods and the theoretical frameworks that inform qualitative inquiry. Additionally, this course focuses on tools for data collection such as individual and focus-group interviewing and observing and recording interaction. This course provides practical experience for students in collecting and analyzing qualitative data with and without the use of technology and examines particular difficulties in the interpretation and reporting of qualitative findings. Qualitative Research Methods is course that bridges disciplinary boundaries and is useful to any student who will be investigating human interaction.

courses.title: Communication Ethics (WAC)
courses.description: Ethical issues in public and private communication; role of communication in expressing and realizing individual and social values.

courses.title: Experiential Learning Portfolio
courses.description: Students will learn how to assemble a portfolio that reflects their progress, knowledge, and insight into college-level study.

courses.title: Independent Studies
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

courses.title: Professional Public Speaking
courses.description: Organizing, adapting and presenting ideas in public informative, persuasive, technical and ceremonial speeches.

courses.title: Argumentation
courses.description: This course provides an in-depth examination of argumentation in both public and private contexts.

courses.title: Business and Professional Communication
courses.description: Review and practice of various communication forms used in modern organizations.

courses.title: Communication and Civility
courses.description: Communication behaviors contributing to civil and uncivil discourse; their implications in business, public life, across cultures and in interpersonal relationships.

courses.title: Interpersonal Communication
courses.description: This class is designed as an opportunity to explore the complexities of interpersonal communication and to develop a repertoire of interpersonal communication skills.

courses.title: Intercultural Communication
courses.description: Focus on topics such as language, identity, prejudice, and intergroup relations on a domestic/ international level.

courses.title: Social Influence
courses.description: Explores how humans influence others through communication.

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.description: Examines the function and structure of communication in both formal and informal situations.

courses.title: Advanced Technical Writing and Editing
courses.description: Preparing and editing professional papers for subject specialists and for others interested in careers as writers or editors.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202A,ENGL 202B,ENGL 202C,ENGL 202D

courses.title: Advanced Business Writing
courses.description: Preparing and editing reports and presentations common to business, industry, and government.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202A,ENGL 202B,ENGL 202C,ENGL 202D

courses.title: Writing for the Web
courses.description: Analysis and composition of informative, persuasive, and "creative" Web texts, based on rhetorical principles; no prior Web writing experience required.

courses.title: Gender Roles in Communications
courses.description: Explores the literature on gender research in the discipline of human communication.

courses.description: History and criticism of public discourse; intensive analysis of selected public addresses and social movements.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 6 credits of CAS

courses.title: Principles of Strategic Communications
courses.description: Provides an overview of the various media and communications methods that comprise modern integrated marketing campaigns.

courses.title: Advanced Technical Writing and Editing
courses.description: Preparing and editing professional papers for subject specialists and for others interested in careers as writers or editors.

courses.title: Advanced Business Writing
courses.description: Preparing and editing reports and presentations common to business, industry, and government.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202A,ENGL 202B,ENGL 202C,ENGL 202D

courses.title: Writing for the Web
courses.description: Analysis and composition of informative, persuasive, and "creative" Web texts, based on rhetorical principles; no prior Web writing experience required.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Theory- and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Surveys the theory, research, and practice related to the communication processes by which individuals in groups and organizations exercise influence, whether or not they occupy positions of acknowledged leadership.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision-making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Leadership in a Global Context
courses.description: This course explores the science and practice of leadership around the globe through pertinent scholarly literature and related instructional resources.

15 credits

3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.

courses.title: Communication Research Methods
courses.description: Overview of the skills necessary to evaluate commonly reported communication research.

courses.title: Rhetorical Theory
courses.description: History and theory of public advocacy and civic discourse.

courses.title: Introduction to Communication Theory
courses.description: This course is intended as a foundational course in communication theory for Communication Arts and Sciences majors and others interested in social science theory in general. It is designed to show how communication theory can be applied to understand and improve communication in your professional (and personal) life. The theories examined will span the range of communication contexts, including interpersonal, group, organizational, mediated, and cross-cultural interactions.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: An understanding of both qualitative research methods and the theoretical frameworks that inform qualitative inquiry. Additionally, this course focuses on tools for data collection such as individual and focus-group interviewing and observing and recording interaction. This course provides practical experience for students in collecting and analyzing qualitative data with and without the use of technology and examines particular difficulties in the interpretation and reporting of qualitative findings. Qualitative Research Methods is course that bridges disciplinary boundaries and is useful to any student who will be investigating human interaction.

courses.title: Communication Ethics
courses.description: Ethical issues in public and private communication; role of communication in expressing and realizing individual and social values.

courses.title: Experiential Learning Portfolio
courses.description: Students will learn how to assemble a portfolio that reflects their progress, knowledge, and insight into college-level study.

courses.title: Research Methods in Sociology
courses.description: Experiential-based course covering the four main social research methods: available data, survey research, experiments, and field research.

courses.title: Independent Studies
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: In addition to required courses in organizational leadership, you will also choose from courses in communication arts and sciences; crime, law, and justice; labor and employment relations; management; philosophy; political science; psychology; and sociology.
curriculumDescription:
This program requires that you complete a minimum of 120 credits.
A student enrolled in this major must receive a grade of C or better in all courses required for the major.
Select 3–4 credits at the 400-level from the following list of courses. Courses that are used in the Additional Courses category may not be double-counted to satisfy this requirement.

Or any 400-level course from:
ACCTG, AFAM, AFR, AGBM, AMST, ANTH, ASIA, BA, BBH, BLAW, CAS, CEDEV, COMM, CRIM, CRIMJ, ECON, EDUC, ENTR, FIN, FR, GER, HIST, HDFS, HLS, HPA, IB, IST, IT, LA, LAS, LAWSC, LHR, MATH, MGMT, MIS, MKTG, OLEAD, PHIL, PLSC, PSYCH, PUBPL, RUS, SCM, SOC, SPAN, STAT, WMNST

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.

15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

Among the degree requirements, students should incorporate at least:
3 credits in U.S. cultures
3 credits in international (IL) cultures
3 credits in writing-across-the-curriculum courses
The course list includes only courses offered by World Campus. An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Introduction to Leadership
courses.description: This course introduces key leadership concepts and practices based on current theory and research. It is designed to help students to discover the knowledge and skills that are characteristic of effective leaders.

courses.title: Organizational Theory and Functions for Leaders
courses.description: Examines the nature of organizations along with its various interconnected functions such as leadership, financial, communications, technology, production, sales, etc.

courses.title: Evidence-Based Leadership
courses.description: Starts by examining different kinds of evidence and analyzing their quality and usefulness; students can then learn how to use that evidence to improve their leadership.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Theory- and research-based communication skills for leaders dealing with work-related problems in contemporary groups and organizations.

courses.title: Communication Skills for Leaders in Groups and Organizations
courses.description: Surveys the theory, research, and practice related to the communication processes by which individuals in groups and organizations exercise influence, whether or not they occupy positions of acknowledged leadership.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision-making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Collective Decision-Making
courses.description: Application of theories of decision making to work-related issues in groups and organizations requiring collective resolution and action.

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.

courses.title: Work Attitudes and Motivation
courses.description: Survey of theory and research with respect to attitudes, morale, and motivation of employees and management.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100;PSYCH 200orSTAT 200

allSections.sectionDescription: Select one course from each area.

courses.title: Information, People, and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.
courses.additionalInfo: Note The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Critical Thinking
courses.description: Discussion of the validity, soundness, and fallacies of everyday language use and reasoning; informal logic; and manipulative arguments and propaganda.
courses.additionalInfo: GH The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Humanities (GH) requirement.

courses.title: Understanding Employee Behavior
courses.description: The course will be offered at an introductory level. It is designed to encourage students to explore individual and group behavior at work.

courses.title: Introduction to Industrial-Organizational Psychology
courses.description: Personnel selection, training, accident prevention, morale, and organizational behavior.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite PSYCH 100

courses.title: Conflict Resolution and Negotiation
courses.description: Theories and strategies important for conceptualizing, developing, and managing conflict negotiation, mediation, and third-party intervention.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3rd Semester Standing or 6 credits of CAS

courses.title: Research Methods in Labor Studies and Employment Relations
courses.description: The objective of this course is to enhance students' abilities to use a range of methodologies to evaluate and conduct research in the field of employment relations and human resource management.

courses.title: Workplace Dispute Resolution
courses.description: This course examines dispute resolution procedures in unionized and nonunion workplaces.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100or 3 other credits of LHR or 6th 5th Semester standing

courses.title: Research Methods in Sociology
courses.description: Experiential-based course covering the four main social research methods: available data, survey research, experiments, and field research.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits in Sociology

courses.title: Ethics in the Workplace
courses.description: Explores ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100or fifth-semester standing or 3 other credits of LHR

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (select 3–4 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: Select 3–4 credits at the 400-level from the following list of courses. Courses that are used in the Additional Courses category may not be double-counted to satisfy this requirement.

courses.title: Leadership Development: A Lifelong Learning Perspective
courses.description: The course examines the continuing influence of social and environmental factors in shaping leadership and leadership development.

courses.title: Leadership in a Global Context
courses.description: This course explores the science and practice of leadership around the globe through pertinent scholarly literature and related instructional resources.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite OLEAD 100and sixth-semester standing

courses.title: Women and Leadership
courses.description: Through the review of literature and research on leadership, problem-solving in leadership scenarios, and self-assessment, students will gain a working definition of leadership and identify and develop leadership traits/competencies to encourage more women to be successful future leaders.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite OLEAD 100and sixth-semester standing

courses.title: OLEAD Internship
courses.description: Supervised practicum in organizational leadership.

courses.title: Independent Study
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

courses.title: Social Influence and Small Groups
courses.description: The study of social influence, leadership and status, and social cohesion and commitment processes in small groups.

courses.title: Work and Occupations
courses.description: Work and occupational life in modern society; work in the past, present, and future.

courses.title: Gender, Occupations, and Professions
courses.description: The role of gender in shaping contemporary North American patterns of employment, occupational roles, and statuses.

courses.title: Workplace Dispute Resolution

courses.title: Research Methods in Sociology
courses.description: Experiential-based course covering the four main social research methods: available data, survey research, experiments, and field research.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite 3 credits in Sociology

courses.title: Ethics in the Workplace
courses.description: Explores ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite LHR 100or fifth-semester standing or 3 other credits of LHR

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

An official degree audit or the recommended academic plan for this program may include additional course options and detailed requirements. All students are expected to complete at least 36 Penn State credits to earn this degree. Please consult an academic adviser for details.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: This organizational leadership program’s prescribed core courses focus on contemporary labor management, organizational psychology, and leadership issues. Many different course options are available to fulfill the remainder of the program, allowing you to customize a portion of your learning to target specific goals.
curriculumDescription:
Foundational courses in psychology, sociology, communication, economics, and labor and employment relations can prepare you for leadership positions in multiple fields, while electives allow you to investigate workplace issues like conflict management and ethics.
This program can help you develop the skills most sought after by employers, including:
exercising influence
complex problem-solving
teamwork
critical thinking
sound judgment
leadership development
motivating a team
conflict management
communication
The Bachelor of Science in Organizational Leadership program requires that students complete a minimum of 120 credits.
The degree's 34 credits of prescribed core courses focus on contemporary labor management and supervisory leadership issues. Many different course options are available to fulfill the remainder of the program, allowing you to customize the degree to meet your specific goals.
A student enrolled in this major must receive a grade of C or better in all courses required for the major.

Select 18–19 credits from the following 400-level. Courses that are used in the Additional Courses category may not be double-counted to satisfy this requirement.
Students should consult with an adviser when selecting courses.

Or any 400-level course from:
ACCTG, AFAM, AFR, AGBM, AMST, ANTH, ASIA, BA, BBH, BLAW, CAS, CEDEV, COMM, CRIM, CRIMJ, ECON, EDUC, ENTR, FIN, FR, GER, HIST, HDFS, HLS, HPA, IB, IST, IT, LA, LAS, LAWSC, LHR, MATH, MGMT, MIS, MKTG, OLEAD, PHIL, PLSC, PSYCH, PUBPL, RUS, SCM, SOC, SPAN, STAT, WMNST

coursesTabContent.programIntro:
You can develop analytical reasoning and critical thinking skills while gaining substantive expertise in one or more areas of political science. Students can orient their course work in several areas, including:
American politics
international relations
comparative politics
curriculumDescription:
This degree provides maximum flexibility when selecting classes, allowing you to tailor your program of study to suit your goals for specialized or general knowledge of politics and related fields. Upper-level courses in the political science program emphasize research-based writing projects that allow you to hone sought-after skills.
In meeting these requirements, students must take at least one course at any level from four of the five fields offered in the department:
American Politics
— PLSC 1, 210N, 404, 429, 447, 468, 471, 472, 473, 480W, and 490
Comparative Politics
— PLSC 3, 200N, and 456
International Relations
— PLSC 14, 410, 412, 418W, 438, 439, 442, and 467
Political Methodology
— PLSC 10, 308, 309, and 410
Political Theory
— PLSC 7N and 17N
A grade of C or better is required for all courses in the major.

At least 9 of the any level credits must be at the 100 level or above. Up to 6 of the any level credits may be taken in related or complementary disciplines with approval of an academic adviser. Select 15 credits at the 400 level.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.

Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.
