allSections.sectionTitle: Prescribed Courses for the Major (30 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses for the major.

courses.title: Overview of Information Security
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the overview of information security, including security architecture, access control, and internet secure applications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 111andIST 110andCMPSC 101

courses.title: Information, People, and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Information Science and Technology
courses.description: Legal environment of information technology, constitutional/political issues, intellectual property, management, e-commerce, privacy, access, computer contracting, cyberspace regulation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 301orSRA 231

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor
Note Internships provide valuable experience for students; however, we recognize that situations vary and some students, due to work or other commitments, are unable to adjust their schedules. You are encouraged to contact your adviser to make arrangements for suitable activities in lieu of an internship.

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.

courses.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SRA 111andCMPSC 101orIST 140andCMPSC 121
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Decision Theory and Analysis
courses.description: Provides an overview of decision theoretical and analytical concepts and tools in the security risk analysis field.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 211,STAT 200

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

allSections.sectionTitle: Additional Courses for the Major (21–23 credits)

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Social Problems
courses.description: Current social problems such as economic, racial, and gender inequalities; social deviance and crime; population, environmental, energy, and health problems.
courses.additionalInfo: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Economic Principles of Agribusiness Decision Making
courses.description: This course introduces students to microeconomic principles in the context of food and agriculture.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: College Algebra II
courses.description: Relations, functions, graphs; polynomial, rational functions, graphs; word problems; nonlinear inequalities; inverse functions; exponential, logarithmic functions; conic sections; simultaneous equations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 021or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Plane Trigonometry
courses.description: Trigonometric functions; solutions of triangles; trigonometric equations; identities.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 21 or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 22orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Geography of International Affairs
courses.description: Contemporary international affairs in their geographical setting; geographic elements in the development of national power, political groupings, and international disputes.

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: Statistics for Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This course emphasizes how to summarize data using descriptive statistics, how to make data-driven decisions using inferential statistics, and how to critically evaluate data presented in the media, all within the context of security, risk, and analysis. This is both a theory and application course. Students will learn about statistical theories, such as regression, and chi-square analyses, and apply their knowledge of these theories by analyzing and interpreting data using a statistical software package.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate Applied Statistics
courses.description: Review of hypothesis testing, goodness-of-fit tests, regression, correlation analysis, completely randomized designs, randomized complete block designs, latin squares.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200orSTAT 240orSTAT 250orSTAT 401
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
courses.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 110or prerequisite or concurrentMATH 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development
courses.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level ofMATH 21in the mathematics placement test.
Recommend preparation MATH 22
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

allSections.sectionTitle: Prescribed Courses for the Intelligence Analysis and Modeling Option (21 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses for the option.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Privacy and Security
courses.description: Exploration of legal, regulatory, public policy, and ethical issues related to security and privacy for information technology professionals in public institutions, private enterprise, and IT services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 432

courses.title: Visual Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental principles, methods, and tools of visual analytics that enable security and risk analysts to synthesize information and derive insight from massive, dynamic, ambiguous, and often conflicting data.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: This course provides students with the background, experience, and perspective required to document risk and identify policies and procedures that effectively deal with hazards and threats to which the organization is vulnerable, jeopardizing its mission.

courses.title: The Intelligence Environment
courses.description: The course examines the users and processes of Intelligence Community, participants of Competitive Intelligence, and comparative intelligence communities.

courses.title: Deception and Counterdeception
courses.description: Deception tactics, technologies and procedures, and approaches to counterdeception analysis.

courses.title: Security and Risk Analysis Capstone Course
courses.description: The Security and Risk Analysis Capstone course is designed to provide IST students enrolled in the SRA major to experience a semester-long security and risk problem-solving experience, providing realistic security dilemmas requiring a solution process that is well suited for teamwork and collaboration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 221andSRA 311andENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courses.title: Spatial Analysis of Risks
courses.description: Helps students develop a spatial perspective on risk analysis and empowers them with GIS spatial data representation, visualization, and analysis methods that are fundamental to the spatial analysis of risk.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 111

allSections.sectionTitle: Prescribed Courses for the Information and Cybersecurity Option (15 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses for the option.

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Information Security Management
courses.description: Contemporary security issues; security management processes, architecture, and models; risk analysis and management; security planning, analysis, and safeguards; security policies development and administration; contingency planning, incidence handling, and response; and security standards and certification processes.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: Assessment and mitigation of security vulnerabilities for people, organizations, industry sectors, and the nation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 231

allSections.sectionTitle: Additional Courses for the Information and Cybersecurity Option (select 3 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses for the option.

courses.title: Information Sciences and Technology Integration and Problem Solving
courses.description: Problem-based approach to technology integration by focusing on real-life problems faced by an organization.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202CorENGL 202Dand seventh-semester standing (this course is intended for seniors)

courses.title: Security and Risk Analysis Capstone Course
courses.description: The Security and Risk Analysis Capstone course is designed to provide IST students enrolled in the SRA major to experience a semester-long security and risk problem-solving experience, providing realistic security dilemmas requiring a solution process that is well suited for teamwork and collaboration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 221andSRA 311andENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: Statistics for Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This course emphasizes how to summarize data using descriptive statistics, how to make data-driven decisions using inferential statistics, and how to critically evaluate data presented in the media, all within the context of security, risk, and analysis. This is both a theory and application course. Students will learn about statistical theories, such as regression, and chi-square analyses, and apply their knowledge of these theories by analyzing and interpreting data using a statistical software package.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate Applied Statistics
courses.description: Review of hypothesis testing, goodness-of-fit tests, regression, correlation analysis, completely randomized designs, randomized complete block designs, latin squares.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite STAT 200orSTAT 240orSTAT 250orSTAT 401
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
courses.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 110or prerequisite or concurrentMATH 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development
courses.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level ofMATH 21in the mathematics placement test.
Recommend preparation MATH 22
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courseSections.sectionTitle: Prescribed Courses for the Intelligence Analysis and Modeling Option (21 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses for the option.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Privacy and Security
courses.description: Exploration of legal, regulatory, public policy, and ethical issues related to security and privacy for information technology professionals in public institutions, private enterprise, and IT services.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite IST 432

courses.title: Visual Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental principles, methods, and tools of visual analytics that enable security and risk analysts to synthesize information and derive insight from massive, dynamic, ambiguous, and often conflicting data.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: This course provides students with the background, experience, and perspective required to document risk and identify policies and procedures that effectively deal with hazards and threats to which the organization is vulnerable, jeopardizing its mission.

courses.title: The Intelligence Environment
courses.description: The course examines the users and processes of Intelligence Community, participants of Competitive Intelligence, and comparative intelligence communities.

courses.title: Deception and Counterdeception
courses.description: Deception tactics, technologies and procedures, and approaches to counterdeception analysis.

courses.title: Security and Risk Analysis Capstone Course
courses.description: The Security and Risk Analysis Capstone course is designed to provide IST students enrolled in the SRA major to experience a semester-long security and risk problem-solving experience, providing realistic security dilemmas requiring a solution process that is well suited for teamwork and collaboration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 221andSRA 311andENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courses.title: Spatial Analysis of Risks
courses.description: Helps students develop a spatial perspective on risk analysis and empowers them with GIS spatial data representation, visualization, and analysis methods that are fundamental to the spatial analysis of risk.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 111

courseSections.sectionTitle: Prescribed Courses for the Information and Cybersecurity Option (15 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all prescribed courses for the option.

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Information Security Management
courses.description: Contemporary security issues; security management processes, architecture, and models; risk analysis and management; security planning, analysis, and safeguards; security policies development and administration; contingency planning, incidence handling, and response; and security standards and certification processes.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: Assessment and mitigation of security vulnerabilities for people, organizations, industry sectors, and the nation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 231

courseSections.sectionTitle: Additional Courses for the Information and Cybersecurity Option (select 3 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription: Students must earn a grade of C or better in all additional courses for the option.

courses.title: Information Sciences and Technology Integration and Problem Solving
courses.description: Problem-based approach to technology integration by focusing on real-life problems faced by an organization.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 202CorENGL 202Dand seventh-semester standing (this course is intended for seniors)

courses.title: Security and Risk Analysis Capstone Course
courses.description: The Security and Risk Analysis Capstone course is designed to provide IST students enrolled in the SRA major to experience a semester-long security and risk problem-solving experience, providing realistic security dilemmas requiring a solution process that is well suited for teamwork and collaboration.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite SRA 221andSRA 311andENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courseSections.sectionDescription: Students can choose electives in consultation with their adviser.

15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits

GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: Courses cover a wide array of software engineering topics, including discrete mathematics, probability, and statistics, along with relevant topics in computer science and supporting disciplines for a comprehensive look at modern computer software and techniques.
curriculumDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Software Engineering program requires you to complete a minimum of 126 credits including a capstone course. As part of SWENG 480/481, taken during your senior year, you'll be required to complete a capstone project which includes collaborating with fellow students to design, plan, manage, and implement a software system and provide you with experience working with real industries.

The curriculum addresses a variety of software engineering topics for comprehensive coverage of modern software and techniques including:
discrete mathematics
probability and statistics
computer programming
object-oriented methodology
software design
software validation and verification
software security
computer networks

Students transferring directly into the major with less than 45 transferable credits must have a cumulative grade point average of 2.7 or higher and have completed:
8 credits of calculus with analytic geometry,
4 credits of calculus-based physics,
and 4 credits of college chemistry including a laboratory
Students transferring directly into the major with more than 45 transferable credits must have a cumulative grade point average of 2.7 or higher and:
a Behrend campus dean's review is required for all students in order to enter the major directly, as well as for all students who have earned 45 or more transferrable credits
current Penn State students must have a grade point average of 2.0 or higher to enter the major
Entrance Requirement:
In addition to the Carnegie unit and minimum GPA requirements described by University policies, all students applying for entrance to any of the engineering majors at Penn State Behrend must have at least a 2.0 cumulative GPA by the end of the semester prior to applying for entrance to the major and have completed, with a minimum grade of C:
CHEM 110 GN(3),
MATH 140 GQ(4),
MATH 141 GQ(4),
and PHYS 211 GN(4).
These courses must be completed by the end of the semester during which the admission-to-major process is being carried out.
Select 3 credits from an approved list of 400-level courses, in consultation with an adviser, in addition to the following courses:

courses.title: Chemical Principles I
courses.description: First semester of a two-semester, comprehensive general chemistry course that introduces students to the basic principles of chemistry with an emphasis on the relationships between the microscopic structure and the macroscopic properties of matter.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Completion of or placement beyondMATH 22
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Experimental Chemistry I
courses.description: Introduction to quantitative experimentation in chemistry.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite or Concurrent CHEM 110orCHEM 106

courses.title: Digital Design: Theory and Practice
courses.description: Introduction to digital systems and their design.
courses.additionalInfo: Concurrent PHYS 212

courses.title: Microprocessors
courses.description: Microprocessor architecture; memory system design; assembly language programming; interrupts; the stacks and subroutines; memory and I/O inter-facing; serial I/O and data communications; microprocessors applications.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPEN 271 andCMPEN 275
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Operating Systems
courses.description: Resource management in computer systems.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 360
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Communication Networks
courses.description: Data transmission, encoding, link control techniques, network architecture, design, protocols, and multiple access.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (CMPEN 270orCMPEN 271) and(CMPSC 121orCMPSC 201)
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
courses.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110or prerequisite or concurrentMATH 140

courses.title: Intermediate Programming
courses.description: Object-oriented programming, recursion, fundamental data structures (including stacks, queues, linked lists, hash tables, trees, and graphs), the basics of algorithmic analysis, and an introduction to the principles of language translation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 121
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Discrete Mathematics for Computer Science
courses.description: Discrete mathematics and foundations for modern computer science.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 122
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Topics include: conceptual data modeling, relational data model, relational query languages, schema normalization, database/Internet applications, and database system issues.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 221 andENGL 202C
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Programming Language Concepts
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of programming language design, specifications, and implementation; programming language paradigms and features; program verification.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 221orCMPSC 360
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Data Structures and Algorithms
courses.description: Fundamental concepts of computer science: data structures, analysis of algorithms, recursion, trees, sets, graphs, sorting.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 122 and(CMPSC 360orMATH 311W)
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30) and4th semester standing
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Calculus with Analytic Geometry II
courses.description: Derivatives, integrals, applications; sequences and series; analytic geometry; polar coordinates.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 140orMATH 140AorMATH 140BorMATH 140EorMATH 140GorMATH 140H
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Matrices
courses.description: Systems of linear equations; matrix algebra; eigenvalues and eigenvectors; linear systems of differential equations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 110,MATH 140, orMATH 140H

courses.title: Ordinary Differential Equations
courses.description: First- and second-order equations; special functions; Laplace transform solutions; higher order equations.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 141

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts
courses.description: Examination of fundamental principles and processes applicable to the study of management. Not available to students who have taken BA 304.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)and (ECON 102orECON 104) and(MATH 21or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination)
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: General Physics: Mechanics
courses.description: Calculus-based study of the basic concepts of mechanics: motion, force, Newton's laws, energy, collisions, and rotation.
courses.additionalInfo:
Concurrent MATH 140
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: General Physics: Electricity and Magnetism
courses.description: Calculus-based study of the basic concepts of electricity and magnetism.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 140andPHYS 211
Concurrent MATH 141

courses.title: Elementary Probability
courses.description: Combinatorial analysis, axioms of probability, conditional probability and independence, discrete and continuous random variables, expectation, limit theorems, additional topics
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite MATH 141
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Object-Oriented Software Design and Construction
courses.description: Design, documentation, testing, and construction of software using software engineering strategies embodied in object-oriented programming languages.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 122
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Software Engineering
courses.description: Software engineering principles including lifecycle, dependability, process modeling, project management, requires specification, design analysis, implementation, testing, and maintenance.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 122
Concurrent SWENG 311
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Software Architecture
courses.description: The analysis and design of software systems using canonical design patterns.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SWENG 411
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Software Verification, Validation, and Testing
courses.description: Introduction to methods of software verification, validation, and testing; mathematical foundations of testing, reliability models; statistical testing.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SWENG 411 orSTAT 301
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Embedded Real Time Systems
courses.description: The design and implementation of real time systems.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite CMPSC 472orCMPSC 473orCMPEN 441
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Software Engineering Design
courses.description: Concepts of engineering ethics, economy, and project management, senior capstone project selection, and technical communication skills.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SWENG 431
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Software Engineering Project
courses.description: Capstone group design projects in software engineering.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite SWENG 480
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Electrical Circuits and Power Distribution
courses.description: D.C. and A.C. circuits, transformers, single and three-phase distribution systems, A.C. motors and generators.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite PHYS 212
Concurrent MATH 250

allSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (select 9 credits)
allSections.sectionDescription: Select 3 credits from an approved list of 400-level courses, in consultation with an adviser, in addition to the following courses:

courses.title: Applied Machine Learning in Data Science
courses.description: This course will start with an overview of supervised and unsupervised learning, and introduce the associated libraries. It covers basic machine learning concepts, tasks, and workflow using an example classification problem based on K-nearest neighbors, Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-means, and implementation using Python libraries.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite STAT 318andMATH 220 and(CMPSC 122 orCMPSC 132)

courses.title: Engineering Quality and Security in Software
courses.description: This course introduces software quality, the associated quality factors, software errors and the software quality assurance system.

courses.title: Electrical Circuits and Power Distribution
courses.description: D.C. and A.C. circuits, transformers, single and three-phase distribution systems, A.C. motors and generators.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite PHYS 212
Concurrent MATH 250

courseSections.sectionTitle: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (select 9 credits)
courseSections.sectionDescription: Select 3 credits from an approved list of 400-level courses, in consultation with an adviser, in addition to the following courses:

courses.title: Applied Machine Learning in Data Science
courses.description: This course will start with an overview of supervised and unsupervised learning, and introduce the associated libraries. It covers basic machine learning concepts, tasks, and workflow using an example classification problem based on K-nearest neighbors, Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-means, and implementation using Python libraries.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite STAT 318andMATH 220 and(CMPSC 122 orCMPSC 132)

courses.title: Engineering Quality and Security in Software
courses.description: This course introduces software quality, the associated quality factors, software errors and the software quality assurance system.

courseSections.sectionDescription: Select 1 credit in consultation with an adviser.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits

6 credits

9 credits

GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits

These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: In the strategic communications major, you'll have the opportunity to study psychology, statistics, law, research, and other disciplines that can be used to build a solid foundation for effective communication for any company or organization.
curriculumDescription:
The Bachelor of Arts in Strategic Communications program requires you to complete a minimum of 120 credits.
A student enrolled in this major must receive a grade of C or better in all prescribed, additional, and supporting courses required for the major.
Students can earn up to six (6) COMM credits through the
credit-by-portfolio
process.
However, it is important for students to know that completing the credit-by-portfolio process does not guarantee that the credits will be awarded.

If you are a transfer student, the number of credits you must take will vary according to the courses that transfer into the program. Once you are admitted to the program, your assigned academic adviser can help you select courses to fulfill the remaining requirements.
Select 3 credits of COMM courses other than COMM 100 or COMM 120.
Students should choose 26 additional credits to satisfy the electives requirement.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.

Some Bachelor of Arts requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major, General Education courses, or electives. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foreign Language:
0–12 credits
Students must attain 12th credit level of proficiency in one foreign language.
B.A. Fields:
9 credits
Humanities, Social and Behavioral Sciences, Arts, Foreign Languages, Natural Sciences, Quantification (cannot be taken in the area of the student's primary major; foreign language credits in this category must be in a second foreign language or beyond the 12th credit level of proficiency in the first language)
Other Cultures:
0–3 credits
Select 3 credits from approved list. Students may count courses in this category in order to meet other major, minor, elective, or General Education requirements, except for the General Education US/IL requirement.​

If you're ready to see when your courses will be offered, visit our public
LionPATH course search (opens in new window)
to start planning ahead.

courses.title: Basic News Writing Skills
courses.description: Grammar, punctuation, spelling, and word usage skills required of journalists.

courses.title: Writing for Media
courses.description: This course is an introduction to writing for various kinds of mass communication media. Students will practice writing public relations news releases; public information announcements; print, television and radio advertisements; and news stories and editorials. Students will be given weekly writing assignments, some of which will be re-writes of earlier submissions. In-class exercises will include various writing exercises designed to get students more comfortable with writing for media.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 15andENGL 202

courses.title: Principles of Strategic Communications
courses.description: Provides an overview of the various media and communications methods that comprise modern integrated marketing campaigns.

courses.title: Strategic Communications Law
courses.description: Analysis of laws and regulations affecting online advertising and strategic communications.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 428Aand permission of the program

courses.title: Strategic Communications in a Global Environment
courses.description: Framework for applying public relations and advertising tools across media platforms and across cultures.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 428A,COMM 428Dand permission of the program

courses.title: Research & Analytics
courses.description: Online research methods for strategic communication, including web analytics, online surveys, online interviews, and content analysis.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite COMM 428A,STAT 200and permission of the program

courses.title: Social Media Strategies
courses.description: Social media — including social networks, visual content, podcasts, blogs and other collaborative content creation platforms — are changing the field of public relations. To effectively deploy social media to reach brand objectives, public relations professionals need to understand the critical roles of strategy as well as content creation. This course narrows the focus from the broad field of social media to cover the specific tools and best practices needed to conquer current and future use of social media in public relations

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive statistics, frequency distributions, probability, binomial and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.

courses.title: Law of Mass Communications
courses.description: Nature and theories of law; the Supreme Court and press freedom; legal problems of the mass media.

courses.title: News Media Ethics
courses.description: Ethical problems in the practice of journalism; principal public criticisms of news media; case study approach.

courses.title: Sports, Media, and Society
courses.description: Sport and media relationship in American culture.

coursesTabContent.programIntro: In addition to covering such topics as pesticides, turfgrass breeding, genetics, business management, and plant nutrition and fertility, this program encompasses soil science and water quality course work.
curriculumDescription:
This online Bachelor of Science in Turfgrass Science is a 120-credit (minimum) program of study that builds upon the skills attained in the advanced turfgrass management certificate. Students can graduate from this program having received
hands-on training
and the opportunity to learn from knowledge leaders and practitioners in the golf and turf industries.
Through the courses provided in this turfgrass management degree program, students will be able to develop and maintain widely used turfgrass management programs. The courses cover topics such as pesticides, turfgrass breeding, genetics, plant science, soil science, and water quality, so students graduate with an opportunity to be a leader in the industry.
To earn this degree, you must successfully complete:
49 prescribed course credits
27 supporting course credits
13 additional credits
18 of the 45 credits for General Education are included in the requirements for the major
1 elective credit
For help with understanding the credit distribution and requirements for program completion, contact an academic adviser today.
Required courses are supplemented by additional credits selected from a variety of areas to enhance your skills in related fields, such as business management, speech communications, and organic chemistry.
Supplemental courses in the program are available in a variety of formats. Details about each course's delivery method are available in LionPATH.

Supporting Courses (select 27 credits)
Select credits from each of the two categories under supporting courses to fulfill the requirements:
15 credits
in Professional Management and Economics
12 credits
in Professional Agriculture

Electives (select 4 credits)
Elective courses will be chosen in consultation with your adviser.
Note:
Listed prerequisites may be waived by the course instructor if you can demonstrate the required level of competency.

Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits

Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits

Integrative Studies:
6 credits

Exploration:
9 credits

May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.

courses.title: Agribusiness Problem-Solving
courses.description: Development of quantitative problem-solving skills applied to specific examples of agribusiness management problems, using Excel spreadsheets.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite AGBM 101;ECON 102;STAT 200;STAT 240;STAT 250;SCM 200
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Fundamentals of Organic Chemistry I
courses.description: Introduction to organic chemistry, with emphasis on the properties of organic compounds of biochemical importance. Because of duplication of subject matter, students may not receive credit for bothCHEM 202andCHEM 210.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite CHEM 101orCHEM 110,CHEM 110HorCHEM 106

courses.title: Turfgrass Insect Pest Management
courses.description: Introduction to entomology and management of insect pests of cold- and warm-season turfgrass.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Concurrent TURF 235

courses.title: College Algebra I
courses.description: Quadratic equations; equation in quadratic form; word problems; graphing; algebraic fractions; negative and rational exponents; radicals.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite MATH 4or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Turfgrass Disease Management
courses.description: Introduction to biology of turfgrass pathogens and management of cool- and warm-season turfgrass.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite TURF 235

courses.title: Introductory Soil Science
courses.description: A study of soil properties and processes and relationships to land use, plant growth, environmental quality, and society.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

courses.title: Turfgrass Pesticides
courses.description: Covers chemical toxicity, formulations, environmental fate, labels, MSDS, calibration, IPM, safety, handling, storage, and Pennsylvania certification and regulations.

courses.title: The Turfgrass
courses.description: Characterization of the primary plant species used for sports, lawn and utility turf; includes turfgrass morphology, environmental adaptation, and cultural requirements.

courses.title: Turf and Ornamental Weed Control
courses.description: Introduction to the development of integrated weed management strategies utilizing a variety of cultural and chemical methods.

courses.title: Golf Course Irrigation and Drainage
courses.description: A study of irrigation topics with a strong concentration on turfgrass irrigation applications and a focus on surface and subsurface drainage.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite TURF 235
Recommend preparation MATH 21andSOILS 101
Note PLANT 217may not be substituted for TURF 307 for prescribed course credit.

courses.title: Turfgrass Cultural Systems
courses.description: A study of turfgrass maintenance practices and how their interrelationships can be utilized to develop management systems.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite TURF 235
Recommended preparation SOILS 101

courses.title: Turfgrass Edaphology
courses.description: Characterization of soil's physical and chemical properties for the establishment and maintenance of sports turf; includes root zone construction.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite TURF 235
Recommend preparation SOILS 101

courses.title: Turfgrass Nutrition
courses.description: Study of turfgrass nutrition and growth; emphasizing constructed and mineral soil fertility, nutrient uptake and function, and fertilizer-use efficiency.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite TURF 235
Recommended preparation SOILS 101

courses.title: Case Studies in Turfgrass Management
courses.description: Case study and discussion considering integrated management of selected turfgrass sites; emphasis on problem analysis, principle application, and decision-making.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite TURF 235and (TURF 434orTURF 435)
Recommended preparation TURF 238andTURF 425

courses.title: Colloquium
courses.description: Oral presentations developed by students in consultation with the course instructor
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite TURF 495
Note Seventh-semester standing
Note Prerequisites may be waived by the course instructor if student demonstrates required level of competency.

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite Prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor

courses.title: Biology: Basic Concepts and Biodiversity
courses.description: A study of the fundamental concepts of biology, including the evolution of the major groups of organisms. This is the first biology course taken by students who intend to major in biology. It provides a foundation in the basic concepts that govern life, including the evolutionary processes that have led to the biodiversity seen today.

courses.title: Introduction to Plant Biology
courses.description: Cellular structure, organization, and metabolism; plant anatomy and physiological processes; plant reproduction and development; genetics and evolution; relationships and features of plant groups. Students who have passed BIOL 240W may not schedule this course.

courses.title: Horticultural Science
courses.description: Introduction to horticulture with an emphasis on plant domestication, morphology, classification, world food crops, commodities, gardens, propagation, and agrochemicals. The course content deals with the fundamental concepts and specialty areas, which contribute not only to the science and technology involved in horticulture but also to the art.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Introductory Meteorology
courses.description: Nontechnical treatment of fundamentals of modern meteorology and the effects of weather and climate.

courses.title: Understanding Weather Forecasting
courses.description: Fundamental principles of synoptic and physical meteorology, satellite and radar imagery, and data analysis in the setting of mid-latitude weather forecasting.

courses.title: Chemical Principles I
courses.description: First semester of a two-semester, comprehensive general chemistry course that introduces students to the basic principles of chemistry with an emphasis on the relationships between the microscopic structure and the macroscopic properties of matter.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Completion of or placement beyondMATH 22
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to General, Organic and Biochemistry
courses.description: This course is a one-semester rigorous college-level introductory Chemistry course covering the fundamental principles of general, organic, and biochemistry. One year of high school chemistry is strongly recommended.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Completion or placement beyondMATH 21
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Horticultural Science
courses.description: Introduction to horticulture with an emphasis on plant domestication, morphology, classification, world food crops, commodities, gardens, propagation, and agrochemicals. The course content deals with the fundamental concepts and specialty areas, which contribute not only to the science and technology involved in horticulture but also to the art.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.additionalInfo: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Introductory Meteorology
courses.description: Nontechnical treatment of fundamentals of modern meteorology and the effects of weather and climate.

courses.title: Understanding Weather Forecasting
courses.description: Fundamental principles of synoptic and physical meteorology, satellite and radar imagery, and data analysis in the setting of mid-latitude weather forecasting.

courses.title: Chemical Principles I
courses.description: First semester of a two-semester, comprehensive general chemistry course that introduces students to the basic principles of chemistry with an emphasis on the relationships between the microscopic structure and the macroscopic properties of matter.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Completion of or placement beyondMATH 22
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to General, Organic and Biochemistry
courses.description: This course is a one-semester rigorous college-level introductory Chemistry course covering the fundamental principles of general, organic, and biochemistry. One year of high school chemistry is strongly recommended.
courses.additionalInfo:
Prerequisite Completion or placement beyondMATH 21
C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courseSections.sectionDescription:
Some General Education requirements may be satisfied by courses required for the major. Students should work with an adviser to select courses.
Foundations:
15 credits
All courses require a grade of C or better. Inter-Domain courses may not be used for foundations requirements.
Writing/Speaking: 9 credits
Quantification: 6 credits
3-6 credits are selected from mathematics, applied mathematics, and statistics; 3 credits may be selected from computer science or symbolic logic.
Knowledge Domains:
15 credits
Inter-Domain courses may not be used for knowledge domain requirements.
Health and Wellness (GHW): 3 credits
Natural Sciences (GN): 3 credits
Arts (GA): 3 credits
Humanities (GH): 3 credits
Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS): 3 credits
Integrative Studies:
6 credits
Inter-Domain course work: 6 credits
Exploration:
9 credits
Natural Sciences (GN) (may be Inter-Domain): 3 credits
GA, GH, GN, GS, and Inter-Domain courses: 6 credits
May include 3 credits of World Language course work beyond the requirements of the student’s degree program or at the 12th credit level, whichever is higher.
These General Education Requirements are for students who started in summer 2023 or later. Students who started earlier can review the prior version of the
general education requirements
.
